headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Yvonne. Good morning, and welcome to ITW's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me this morning are our CEO, Scott Santi; and our CFO, Michael Larsen. During today's call, we will discuss our first quarter 2016 financial results and upda
componenttext:
Thank you, Yvonne. Good morning, and welcome to ITW's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me this morning are our CEO, Scott Santi; and our CFO, Michael Larsen. During today's call, we will discuss our first quarter 2016 financial results and update you on our 2016 earnings forecast. 
Before we get to the results, let me remind you that this presentation contains our financial forecast for the 2016 second quarter and full year as well as other forward-looking statements identified on this slide. We refer you to this company's 2015 Form 10-K for more detail about important risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. 
Also, this presentation uses certain non-GAAP measures. While we use very few non-GAAP measures, a reconciliation of those non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measure is contained in the press release. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Aaron, and good morning. Overall, a pretty good solid start to the year for ITW as we delivered solid near-term results and continued to make good progress in executing our strategy to position the company to deliver solid growth with best-in-clas
componenttext:
Thanks, Aaron, and good morning. Overall, a pretty good solid start to the year for ITW as we delivered solid near-term results and continued to make good progress in executing our strategy to position the company to deliver solid growth with best-in-class margins and returns. 
In the quarter, we continued to deliver meaningful improvement on all of our key performance metrics. We grew EPS 7%, 10% excluding the impact of foreign currency translation. Organic growth came in at the midpoint of our forecast and was up 1%, 2% excluding the impact of our POS initiatives. We improved operating margin by 120 basis points to 22.1% and increased after-tax return on invested capital by 180 basis points to 21.2%. Both our operating margin and our ROIC metrics were new all-time first quarter highs for the company.
Free cash flow was also strong in the quarter at 90% of net income. Based on current event trends and our strong operational and margin performance in the quarter, we are raising our GAAP EPS guidance for 2016 by $0.05 at the midpoint. 
Before turning the call over to Michael for more detail on our Q1 results, I'd like to thank all of our ITW colleagues around the world for the great job that they continue to do in serving our customers and in executing our strategy. Michael, over to you.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everybody. As you saw this morning, ITW is off to a strong start in 2016 as the company delivered another solid quarter with excellent quality of earnings. GAAP EPS of $1.29 increased 7% versus prior year and exceeded t
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everybody. As you saw this morning, ITW is off to a strong start in 2016 as the company delivered another solid quarter with excellent quality of earnings. GAAP EPS of $1.29 increased 7% versus prior year and exceeded the midpoint of our guidance range by $0.04, driven by better operating margin as a result of strong operational execution on our Enterprise Initiatives. 
Organic revenue was up 1% and in line with our guidance as North America grew 2% and international declined 1%. As Scott mentioned, we established a number of new all-time highs for our first quarter. Operating margin of 22.1% improved 120 basis points, with Strategic Sourcing, 80/20 Practice Excellence and business structure simplification all contributing in a very meaningful way. Given the strong margin performance in the quarter, we now expect that operating margin will exceed 22.5% for the full year.
Operating income of $722 million was also a first quarter record. The prior record of $705 million was pre-enterprise strategy in 2012 and was achieved with revenues that were $1.3 billion higher than this quarter. 
After-tax ROIC was solid. Free cash flow was strong. And we repurchased shares for $500 million. Just to comment on our external financial reporting. As you know, at ITW, we work hard to keep our external reporting simple, consistent and transparent. We only report one EPS number and that is GAAP EPS. There are no adjusted EPS numbers. 
That said, let me just point out 2 items that are included in our first quarter GAAP EPS number of $1.29: first, foreign currency translation, which was right in line with our guidance assumption, an unfavorable $0.04 year-over-year; second, last year's first quarter included a nonrecurring gain on the sale of a business. As a result in the first quarter last year, other income was $21 million compared to $4 million this quarter. Excluding these 2 items, EPS would have increased 13%.
We strongly believe that in current economic environment and over the long term, our highly profitable and diversified portfolio is a core strength of the company. We are very well balanced in terms of our end market and geographic exposures and well positioned to perform at a high level across a wide range of economic scenarios.
Our consumer-facing businesses make up 60% of our revenues and include the Automotive OEM and Food Equipment segments as well as portions of Specialty Products and construction. These businesses continue to deliver stable, high-quality growth. In the first quarter, our consumer-facing businesses were up 3% versus prior year and up 1% sequentially. 
Our industrial-facing businesses such as Welding and Test & Measurement and Electronics account for 40% of our revenues, and as expected, they declined year-over-year. As you can see, these businesses were down 3% but showed some improvement versus Q4 when they were down 6%. As you know, the year-over-year comparisons continue to ease as we go through the year.
1% organic revenue growth in the quarter, 2% excluding our Product Line Simplification initiatives or PLS. By region, North America was up 2% with our consumer-facing businesses up 5%. Solid growth continues in Food Equipment up 5%, Automotive up 4% and construction products with renovation remodeling up 22%. 
Industrial-facing businesses were down 3%, with Welding down 7% and Test & Measurement and Electronics down 1%. On the international side, overall down 1% with Europe up 1% and Asia Pac down 2%. Our international consumer businesses grew 1% and industrial is down 4%, primarily due to Welding.
In ITW, we believe that operating margin is a key indicator of our business's competitive advantage and the efficiency with which they leverage it. It is, in our view, a compelling indicator of the strength and competitiveness of ITW and is a key performance metric for every ITW business. 
In the first quarter, operating margin improved 120 basis points to 22.1% as 6 of our 7 segments improved. Construction Products increased 440 basis points, Specialty Products 350 basis points, Food Equipment up 190 basis points and Automotive was up 140 basis points, to mention a few. Approximately half of the decline in Welding this quarter is related to restructuring and other nonoperating items, and the team continues to do a good job in a challenging environment, as evidenced by the ability to sustain operating margins in the mid-20s despite a significant decline in revenue.
You can also see the positive impact of volume leverage in the faster growing segments, which gives you a sense for what margins and overall profitability will look like as organic growth picks up. On the right side of the page, we listed the drivers of our operating margin improvement this quarter, starting with 130 basis points from our self-help Enterprise Initiatives. Given the strong performance and positive momentum, we are now expecting more than 100 basis points from Enterprise Initiatives this year.
Price/cost came in as expected, stable and favorable at 20 basis points. The unfavorable 50 basis points in the other line is primarily related to investments in growth and overhead inflation. Overall, continued strong execution in Enterprise Initiatives and progress on delivering best-in-class margins consistently and sustainably.
Before we get into the segment results, we listed the quarterly progression on operating margin expansion since the first quarter of 2013, 520 basis point at the enterprise level. As you can see, construction improved 930 basis points, 780 basis points in Food Equipment and more than 600 basis points in Automotive and Specialty Products. Overall, good progress with more to come.
Turning to the segments. Automotive OEM had another strong quarter with organic revenue up 3% and 26.4% operating margin. While 3% organic growth is a little below what we've seen out of our Automotive OEM segment over the last several quarters, the segment had a very tough comp, and Q1 revenue came in right where we planned it to be. 
In the first quarter of last year, the launch of several new programs in Europe resulted in revenue growth of 13% versus build of 2%, which is what created the tough comp for the business this year. Our long-term growth target for our Automotive OEM business remains 2 to 4 percentage points of above-market growth annually, and based on already sold programs and our new program pipeline, we expect to meet or exceed that target both in 2016 and for at least the next several years beyond.
In North America, 4% organic growth compares to auto build of up 5% and the Detroit 3 up 4%. China was up 6% in the quarter despite the fact that builds at Western OEMs were down slightly. As expected, operating margin improved 140 basis points to 26.4%, the highest in the company. 
A quick update on the acquisition of EF&C from ZF TRW that we announced last quarter. The acquisition remains on track and we expect the deal to close midyear. As a reminder, EF&C should be modestly accretive to EPS in the first 12 months, with accelerating benefits in 2017 and beyond.
Another strong quarter in Food Equipment, up 3% organically with strength in North America up 5% despite a challenging comparison. North America equipment was up 5%, with strength in refrigeration and cooking and service was up 4%. International was up 1%, with equipment up 3% and service flat. Continued strong margin performance as operating margin improved by 190 basis points to 24.5%. 
Test & Measurement and Electronics organic revenue down 2%. Test & Measurement down 3% and Electronics slightly better at down 1%. Sequentially, the segment was stable, down 7% compared to typical seasonality of down 6%.
Still a challenging external environment for our Welding business as organic revenue declined 9%. The 9% year-over-year decline breaks down as 5 points from oil and gas, 3 points from industrial and 1 point from commercial. North America was down 7%, with equipment down 10% and consumables down 1%. International was down 15%, primarily due to oil and gas. 
We saw some slowing sequentially with demand trends down 3% compared to the typical 3% increase, and the team continues to take appropriate action on the cost side. As I mentioned earlier, approximately half of the operating margin decline in Welding this quarter is related to restructuring and other nonoperating items.
Polymers & Fluids achieved positive organic revenue growth of 1%. North America and international were both up 1% and Automotive Aftermarket improved 2%.
Strong quarter in Construction Products as organic revenue increased 5%, with North America up 11%. Renovation remodeling was up 22%, commercial was up 8% and residential was up 2%. Asia Pacific was up 2% and Europe flat. Very strong progress in operating margin, up 440 basis points to 21%.
Solid quarter in Specialty Products, with organic revenue up 3%, with strength in our consumer packaging businesses. North America was up 5% and international was flat. And very strong progress on operating margin with an increase of 350 basis points to 26.1%.
So for the year, based on our margin performance in the first quarter, we are raising our full year EPS guidance by $0.05 to a new range of $5.40 to $5.60, the $5.50 midpoint is 7% earnings growth. Our organic revenue  growth expectation of 1% to 3% is unchanged and in line with current run rates. 
We're forecasting that Enterprise Initiatives will deliver more than 100 basis points of margin improvement and that full year operating margin will exceed 22.5%. We still expect free cash flow conversion to exceed 100%, and we're targeting $2 billion in share repurchases. 
For the second quarter, our GAAP EPS guidance is $1.34 to $1.44, up 7% at the $1.39 midpoint. That puts 49% of our full year EPS forecast in the first half of the year, which is consistent with prior years. And with that, let me turn the call back to Aaron.

componenttext: First, I want to thank you, by the way, for the GAAP presentation of earnings and frankly for doing a call selective disclosure podcast. So much appreciated. Can we -- and don't answer that. Can you we just talk about currency, Michael? I know you said it was in line with expectations. It was a little bit more of a drag just based on where we were marking currencies that we thought would happen in the quarter. So was there -- I realize a lot of exposure in Australian dollar and -- I don't know. Just what the pound and so forth, maybe could you talk about, just give us more color in terms of the currency fluctuation and where you've marked this for the rest of the year and how you expect that to progress in terms of drag or contribution.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So you're heading down the right path here. So you have to look beyond just the euro and if you look at the changes in pound, Canadian and Australian dollar, that's when you get to the 3% translation impact here in the first quarter on the top line
componenttext: Right. So you're heading down the right path here. So you have to look beyond just the euro and if you look at the changes in pound, Canadian and Australian dollar, that's when you get to the 3% translation impact here in the first quarter on the top line and $0.04 of EPS headwind, which was right in line with the assumption we had in our guidance. For the rest of the year, that translation impact will, at current rates, as we sit here today, will be lower. And maybe if you're heading down the path of EPS impact for the balance of the year, it is correct that based on current rates as we sit here today, not just looking at the euro but the other currencies that we mentioned, if currency stays exactly where it is, things could turn out a little bit better. But as you know, there's a lot of volatility in currency. And so we have not included that in the numbers we gave you today.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So my follow-up, I want to ask you and Scott, what do you think of the -- what do you make of the ISM? It's all that everyone seems to look at. And if you look at the new orders component, it sort of tell you that "recovery" is on the . Now last yea
componenttext: Okay. So my follow-up, I want to ask you and Scott, what do you think of the -- what do you make of the ISM? It's all that everyone seems to look at. And if you look at the new orders component, it sort of tell you that "recovery" is on the . Now last year was flashing green and manufacturing was going the other way. So I think I'm just trying to get your sense, you're a real-time company, short cycle here in the economy. Do you think that the ISM is reflecting perhaps some seasonal improvement, some sentiment improvement, only perhaps a little bit of systematic inventory restock? Or are you just seeing a complete disconnect? I just want to again focus in North America please, and how do you, based on your years of experience, how do you interpret the ISM and why frankly would you be even more positive on your outlook?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've never -- from our particular lands, we've never viewed the ISM number as having a terrific correlation to conditions we're seeing on the ground. Certainly not way up, but I think from the standpoint of leading or lagging, it's not been particularly
componenttext: We've never -- from our particular lands, we've never viewed the ISM number as having a terrific correlation to conditions we're seeing on the ground. Certainly not way up, but I think from the standpoint of leading or lagging, it's not been particularly reflective of the conditions that we're seeing. What I will tell you is my take on the quarter is that we saw pretty solid demand throughout. So I think things are relatively firm for right now. The one exception to that is obviously Welding. Hopefully, we're getting close to a bottom but I can't say that we're seeing anything that tells us that. But beyond that, the overall demand profile inside the company was pretty solid as we move through the quarter, so no big movement and certainly not weakening as we move through the quarter.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I'd say it's been pretty firm. I think it's a little early in the quarter to call with one quarter's worth of data. But I think again, in the aggregate, things were pretty solid of the quarter, look at our consumer-facing businesses where the overall demand rates have been pretty solid going back 4, 5 quarters now. I think we're feeling good where we said in the kind of the overall demand picture that we saw in the first quarter. That being said, it's still a pretty choppy environment out there. But there is no new worry based on our first quarter performance that we saw across the company.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess my first question is on auto. Again, and first, solid quarter, but clearly, you guys had a really, really tough comp especially if you look on a 2-year stack. Is the expectation that growth starts to improve beyond the first quarter on your aut
componenttext: So I guess my first question is on auto. Again, and first, solid quarter, but clearly, you guys had a really, really tough comp especially if you look on a 2-year stack. Is the expectation that growth starts to improve beyond the first quarter on your auto business is based on what you know on production schedules and the platforms that you're on?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think we talked about a tough comp in the first quarter due to the new programs launched in Europe. And if you recall, Europe last year was up 11% on builds of 1%. So that comp will be with us for the year. But in terms of the year-over-year organic
componenttext: So I think we talked about a tough comp in the first quarter due to the new programs launched in Europe. And if you recall, Europe last year was up 11% on builds of 1%. So that comp will be with us for the year. But in terms of the year-over-year organic growth rate, as we sit here today, looking at the typical seasonality, Q1 is the low point for the year, and the organic growth rate on a year-over-year basis will improve as we go through the year.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And maybe my follow-on question, moving on to Welding. So clearly, part of the portfolio, there's been a little bit more challenge. You guys mentioned half of the margin performance this quarter was related to restructuring actions. Does that
componenttext: Okay, great. And maybe my follow-on question, moving on to Welding. So clearly, part of the portfolio, there's been a little bit more challenge. You guys mentioned half of the margin performance this quarter was related to restructuring actions. Does that start to tail off as we progress through the year? Or how are you thinking about that business purely on the face of it when you take a look at the detrimental margins, the decremental margins in the first quarter were pretty high. Just trying to get a sense for how that business will to traject for the rest of the year.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we had, as you said, about half of the impact in the first quarter here, the margin declined down 9%, which is a pretty significant organic. About half of that was restructuring-related. We expect a similar impact here in Q2 and then improvement i
componenttext: Yes, so we had, as you said, about half of the impact in the first quarter here, the margin declined down 9%, which is a pretty significant organic. About half of that was restructuring-related. We expect a similar impact here in Q2 and then improvement in the second half of the year on the margin side. And obviously, the comparisons get significantly easier in the back half of the year. So last year in the first quarter, Welding was down 3%, which sounds like an easy comp but actually it's not when you look at how the rest of 2015 unfolded. So the comps will get better as we go through this year. Based on current sequential trends that we look at, we'll see flat to positive in the back half. And margins will improve also in the back half. We have another slug of restructuring to get through here in the second quarter and then for now, hopefully, the worst is behind us.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from line of Nigel Coe from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from line of Nigel Coe from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on John's question. Can you hear me?

componenttext: Yes, we hear you.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: So there's some chatter out there that March is a bit weaker than January and February industrial markets. Did you see that? Doesn't sound like you did [indiscernible] comments, Scott.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We did not.
componenttext: We did not.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Good. Moving on to Construction, Construction was a standout this quarter with 5% and 11% in North America. And I'm wondering is there any way to try and understand how much of it is weather-driven, and I'm seeing the construction activity did benef
componenttext: Okay. Good. Moving on to Construction, Construction was a standout this quarter with 5% and 11% in North America. And I'm wondering is there any way to try and understand how much of it is weather-driven, and I'm seeing the construction activity did benefit from weather. And how much being pulled forward from maybe 2Q into Q1. And maybe just characterize that talk about how you [indiscernible] the quarter on Construction Products? Was it pretty steady as well?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the answer to your first question is there's really no way to factor weather in, in terms of how it might have impacted our results relative to whatever you might call a normalized year. So -- which is a big reason why we usually don't bite on any si
componenttext: Yes, the answer to your first question is there's really no way to factor weather in, in terms of how it might have impacted our results relative to whatever you might call a normalized year. So -- which is a big reason why we usually don't bite on any single quarter trends in construction as predictive or indicative of overall demand. I think what I would say is we certainly exited the quarter in pretty good shape there, so I think we're not seeing anything slow down or ease up. And we'll hope it continues through the balance of the year for sure.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just a quick follow-up on construction. Europe is flat and we're seeing some signs of maybe green shoots and production activity in Europe. But I know that U.K. is an important end market. So I'm wondering, can you just talk about what yo
componenttext: Okay, great. And just a quick follow-up on construction. Europe is flat and we're seeing some signs of maybe green shoots and production activity in Europe. But I know that U.K. is an important end market. So I'm wondering, can you just talk about what you've seen in Europe? Is the U.K. in a slow down in Europe and you're seeing some green shoots in continental Europe?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're not seeing anything slowdown. We're in a bit of a lagger in terms of when our products are actually going onto the job. It's well after the start phase. So I think in terms of color, our -- the overall sort of macro view over there from the stan
componenttext: No, we're not seeing anything slowdown. We're in a bit of a lagger in terms of when our products are actually going onto the job. It's well after the start phase. So I think in terms of color, our -- the overall sort of macro view over there from the standpoint of construction is things are heading in the right direction.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Andrew Kaplowitz from Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Andrew Kaplowitz from Citigroup.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: More than your 4 years in [indiscernible] strategy and Q1 '16 appears to be your best quarter really in the last 4 years in terms of margin and contribution from the strategy. So what's surprising is we would think that, given tougher comparisons and give
componenttext: More than your 4 years in [indiscernible] strategy and Q1 '16 appears to be your best quarter really in the last 4 years in terms of margin and contribution from the strategy. So what's surprising is we would think that, given tougher comparisons and given you're now obviously more than halfway done with your initiative, you're hitting this kind of a performance. Can you give us a little more color as to what's going on? Is it just your team is now better at implementing your initiatives than earlier in their program? Or is it that you're tackling more complicated areas of your business such as European construction or Specialty Products that you actually find it easier to improve efficiency?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would probably say is that we are -- these were not a series of initiatives that were implemented simultaneously so we are basically sequencing through. If you look at the progression that we laid out and we talked about this, early on, we we
componenttext: Well, what I would probably say is that we are -- these were not a series of initiatives that were implemented simultaneously so we are basically sequencing through. If you look at the progression that we laid out and we talked about this, early on, we were heavily focused on the portfolio business structure simplification. Sourcing, we said all along, had a ramp. If you remember that, I think it was now famously known as the heat map from our first presentation. And then we had an initiative that was related to what we call business model excellence. It's reapplying the ITW business model to the much more focused businesses. And so what we're seeing today is much more now of an impact from sourcing the later stage stuff. So it wasn't necessarily an all-at-once sort of level of execution across all those initiatives. They were very intentionally laid out in a sequence because we had to get certain things done that will allow us to get to the next phase things. So some of the improvement that we're seeing is just now sourcing and business model excellence starting to take over from BSS and the portfolio work that we did. And the other thing, I would say, is you're starting to see some impact from incremental contribution from organic growth as was in to make the pivot to growth and Michael showed you a chart earlier but if you look at where we had the best margin performance in the quarter, it was in the parts of the company that were generating most organic growth. So the elevated level of profitability in incremental profit we generate, every dollar of organic is now starting to contribute as we move into this next phase of our strategies.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me ask about you the pivot of growth. You've talked before that 85% of your businesses is being ready to grow by the end of '16 from 60%, I guess, at the end the last year. So how many more businesses or even should we be thinking like this did you
componenttext: So let me ask about you the pivot of growth. You've talked before that 85% of your businesses is being ready to grow by the end of '16 from 60%, I guess, at the end the last year. So how many more businesses or even should we be thinking like this did you convert in 1Q as ready to grow? And when you do convert these, are you seeing the growth progression of those businesses that you expect? And you saw the percentage headwind on growth in PLS in the quarter. I think you thought about 90 bps [ph] for the year. How does that progression work out? Does it start falling -- does the headwind start falling significantly just at the very end of the year or does it start falling now?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, to start with the last part first, the portfolio work that we're doing at the product line level at some point is going to dissipate. I think we are -- frankly, we're -- there's still a fair amount of that to do heading into '16. We won't know what
componenttext: Well, to start with the last part first, the portfolio work that we're doing at the product line level at some point is going to dissipate. I think we are -- frankly, we're -- there's still a fair amount of that to do heading into '16. We won't know what that looks like for '17 fully until we get to the end of the planning cycle, but I would say we're certainly moving in the direction of the getting to the tail end of that. And it will not be some ongoing maintenance that we do, but it will not be something we will talk about anymore, won't have a significant impact at some point. It is a process that takes some time to work through. We have to move customers from product A to product B. It's not something that we can just -- we just stop selling something. So it does take some work, and it's a process attached to it but I would expect that, that number in '17 will be lower than it was in '16. And certainly by the end of '17, that should be a nonfactor. On the first part of your question, we are sort of executing the plan that we laid out. We are -- I can't give you a number for how many across of the transition line from preparing-to-grow to ready-to-grow in the first quarter, but we've got a lot of planning around hitting that 85% level by year-end. And at that point, those businesses start to change their focus to grow, I would certainly note that it's not necessarily something where we look for an immediate ramp. But ultimately, what it means is a significant part of their organizational energy and effort, 75%-plus start to go into focusing on fully leveraging their organic growth potential. And from that, we certainly expect a change in growth rate velocity inside those businesses. I think we've already shown that in places like Food Equipment and Automotive that have been the furthest ones down the path.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Raso from Evercore ISI.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know you maintained your organic sales growth guidance in total as well as total company sales. But maybe I missed it but did you change your outlook at all within the business segments? Any particular markets, be it global auto builds, construction sta
componenttext: I know you maintained your organic sales growth guidance in total as well as total company sales. But maybe I missed it but did you change your outlook at all within the business segments? Any particular markets, be it global auto builds, construction starts? I mean, any color you can give us on changes within that keeping the total [indiscernible].

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, David, we didn't change anything by segment. So when we look at our internal planning, like we said, Automotive as well as the other segments, we're right on track in Q1 and so we haven't changed anything in terms of our outlook for the year by segmen
componenttext: No, David, we didn't change anything by segment. So when we look at our internal planning, like we said, Automotive as well as the other segments, we're right on track in Q1 and so we haven't changed anything in terms of our outlook for the year by segments.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then given the auto acquisition still hopefully going to be closed here relatively soon, but the M&A front obviously was not that big a deal you're still [indiscernible] other things. Can you give us an update on how we should think about M&A as we mo
componenttext: And then given the auto acquisition still hopefully going to be closed here relatively soon, but the M&A front obviously was not that big a deal you're still [indiscernible] other things. Can you give us an update on how we should think about M&A as we move further into the year into next year?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are still focused on working the plan, which is not -- M&A is not a big priority. We have what we think is a terrific opportunity that we brought in, in this auto business and we're focused on getting that one closed. There's -- and we talked abou
componenttext: Yes, we are still focused on working the plan, which is not -- M&A is not a big priority. We have what we think is a terrific opportunity that we brought in, in this auto business and we're focused on getting that one closed. There's -- and we talked about where these -- or at least hitting our strategy. This is -- we're going to -- we'll look at things that we think can further support our reinforce the organic growth strategy of our 7 segments, and there's probably 2 or 3 little bolt-on floating around at any given time. But not a big priority. Our big priority is continue to move down the path of executing these initiatives internally, getting ourselves very focused then at fully leveraging the organic growth potential for all the reasons I talked about earlier with incremental profitability for every dollar of organic revenue growth is, by far, the most accretive thing we can do.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And lastly, I apologize if I missed it, but the share repo for the quarter, what was it?
componenttext: Okay. And lastly, I apologize if I missed it, but the share repo for the quarter, what was it?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: $500 million, in line with the planning that we laid out. So think of the $2 billion as $500 million per quarter is the way we've planned it out.
componenttext: $500 million, in line with the planning that we laid out. So think of the $2 billion as $500 million per quarter is the way we've planned it out.

componenttext: Our next question comes from line of Deane Dray from RBC.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: I was hoping you'd give us an update on price/cost in the quarter and then the outlook, given some of the changes for some of the raws like steel for the balance of the year.

componenttext: Yes. So price/cost, like I said, was 20 basis points for the quarter, right in line with our planning assumption, right in line with what we saw last year. And that's -- that remains our assumption for the rest of the year. Nothing unusual again this quarter by segment, everything is on track. So that's the color I can give you.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just to go back on the comment at the beginning regarding the emphasis on GAAP earnings. And I think I certainly applaud that. I know from a quality of earnings standpoint that, that gets recognized. And so I was interested in hearing tha
componenttext: Got it. And then just to go back on the comment at the beginning regarding the emphasis on GAAP earnings. And I think I certainly applaud that. I know from a quality of earnings standpoint that, that gets recognized. And so I was interested in hearing that you're doing some what we would call quiet restructuring in Welding. And you've sized that for us. What's the payback that you're expecting on that? And is there any other quiet restructuring going on elsewhere in the segments?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The payback is -- on these projects is typically less than a year. This one is actually quite a bit better than that. It's primarily focused on North America. And we do disclose -- the last page in the press release lays out the restructuring by segment.
componenttext: The payback is -- on these projects is typically less than a year. This one is actually quite a bit better than that. It's primarily focused on North America. And we do disclose -- the last page in the press release lays out the restructuring by segment. And you can see the most significant one was -- is Welding this quarter. Like I said, there will be another series of restructuring here in Welding in Q2. And then we'll kind of update you as we go through the year.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how much of that is cash?
componenttext: And how much of that is cash?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Essentially all cash, but not significant. And when you look at how much cash we generate, this does not -- don't think of it as having an impact on our capital allocation strategy.
componenttext: Essentially all cash, but not significant. And when you look at how much cash we generate, this does not -- don't think of it as having an impact on our capital allocation strategy.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mig Dobre from Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mig Dobre from Baird.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a clarification for me if you would. Looking at Slide #5 where you're talking about your consumer and industrial businesses on a sequential basis. So my understanding is that the sequential number that you're providing are adjusted for seasonality f
componenttext: Maybe a clarification for me if you would. Looking at Slide #5 where you're talking about your consumer and industrial businesses on a sequential basis. So my understanding is that the sequential number that you're providing are adjusted for seasonality for the footnote on the page. I'm looking at industrial businesses being down 5%. I think last quarter, they were up 4% sequentially. So I'm trying to start understanding exactly what's going on in these industrial businesses. And then Welding specifically because that appears to be the driver here. Are things getting incrementally worse in Welding? Or was it simply that we had some sort of a pull-forward demand last quarter?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say there was any pull forward in demand. I mean, the reason for the sequential decline is essentially all Welding. Typically in Q1 versus Q4, we -- like we said, we would expect our Welding business to be up 3% and it was actually down 3%.
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say there was any pull forward in demand. I mean, the reason for the sequential decline is essentially all Welding. Typically in Q1 versus Q4, we -- like we said, we would expect our Welding business to be up 3% and it was actually down 3%. Test & Measurement, which is the other segment in here, was essentially stable from Q4 to Q1. So it's all Welding-driven, Mig.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And I guess, the spirit of my question was others [indiscernible] out there that maybe things are stabilizing and some of these end markets that have been really challenging in 2015. And in Welding, you've got exposure in a lot of them. And what's
componenttext: Right. And I guess, the spirit of my question was others [indiscernible] out there that maybe things are stabilizing and some of these end markets that have been really challenging in 2015. And in Welding, you've got exposure in a lot of them. And what's your read-through based on the way your business is progressing?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as Scott said earlier, I think other than Welding, everything is stable and feels pretty firm as we start the year here. In Welding, we continue to see the impact from energy, oil and gas, which accounts for the decline on the international
componenttext: Well, I think as Scott said earlier, I think other than Welding, everything is stable and feels pretty firm as we start the year here. In Welding, we continue to see the impact from energy, oil and gas, which accounts for the decline on the international side. General fabrication is still a challenge, especially going into mining, agricultural, heavy equipment. So the demand environment in terms of capital equipment going into the industrial economy, we would describe as still sluggish. And as Scott said, we've not seen any sign yet that -- of improvement at this point.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and maybe -- the last thing is when you're talking about volumes maybe being stable to slightly up in Welding in the back half, I'm trying to understand how you think about this business sequentially seasonally.
componenttext: Okay, and maybe -- the last thing is when you're talking about volumes maybe being stable to slightly up in Welding in the back half, I'm trying to understand how you think about this business sequentially seasonally.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mig, that's purely a comparison.
componenttext: Yes, Mig, that's purely a comparison.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Current run rate.
componenttext: Current run rate.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So at current run rates, if you run those out and you look at on a year-over-year basis, that's when you get 9% decline in organic in Q1. You'll get another decline in Q2 and then stable to up in the second half of -- flat to up in the back half of the ye
componenttext: So at current run rates, if you run those out and you look at on a year-over-year basis, that's when you get 9% decline in organic in Q1. You'll get another decline in Q2 and then stable to up in the second half of -- flat to up in the back half of the year. That current run rates, that can obviously change but at current run rates, given the comparisons year-over-year, that's what we would expect to see.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joel Tiss from BMO.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wondered if we can dig a little bit more into the food business? And can you give us any color on the different end markets and what some of the drivers of the improvement were and what the outlook is going to the next couple of quarters?
componenttext: I just wondered if we can dig a little bit more into the food business? And can you give us any color on the different end markets and what some of the drivers of the improvement were and what the outlook is going to the next couple of quarters?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we feel very good about the first quarter, particularly if you look at North America, up 5% on the equipment side, up 4% service. From a product line standpoint, refrigeration and cooking are the big drivers of this quarter. And then by end market
componenttext: Yes, so we feel very good about the first quarter, particularly if you look at North America, up 5% on the equipment side, up 4% service. From a product line standpoint, refrigeration and cooking are the big drivers of this quarter. And then by end market, it's really health care and and continue to be solid for us. But really across-the-board, we feel very good about the outlook for the year. We have a number of new products coming in here in Q2. And so we expect that business to be up similar to last year in that 3% to 4% range as we talked about on the last call.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can we do the same thing for Polymers & Fluids? There's so many different end markets and different pieces. Can you just give us a little deeper color there too?
componenttext: Okay. Can we do the same thing for Polymers & Fluids? There's so many different end markets and different pieces. Can you just give us a little deeper color there too?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I would offer in Polymers & Fluids is it's basically an MRO business. 2/3 but the other 1/3 is the Automotive Aftermarket piece. The Automotive aftermarket side of it had a pretty solid quarter up 2%. I think largely how I would characterize the over
componenttext: What I would offer in Polymers & Fluids is it's basically an MRO business. 2/3 but the other 1/3 is the Automotive Aftermarket piece. The Automotive aftermarket side of it had a pretty solid quarter up 2%. I think largely how I would characterize the overall growth performance in the quarter is they've gotten to the end of a pretty extensive PLS process and are starting to now -- the product line is much more stable than it's been over the last 8 quarters, and they're starting to now turn their attention more to growth. And so very pleased to see positive overall kind of that segment in the quarter.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Andy Casey from Wells Fargo.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Kind of a detailed question to start. On the 50 basis point drag in components and margin that you called out on Slide 7, you mentioned overhead inflation. Could you provide a little bit more detail and what's driving that inflation?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Salary increases.
componenttext: Salary increases.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good for you, guys. Then on the follow-up, if we look at some of the macro data, the inventory-to-sales ratios are relatively high in the U.S. and some areas. Have you guys seen any change in customer inventory actions, meaning destock, restock? Or is it
componenttext: Good for you, guys. Then on the follow-up, if we look at some of the macro data, the inventory-to-sales ratios are relatively high in the U.S. and some areas. Have you guys seen any change in customer inventory actions, meaning destock, restock? Or is it just pretty consistent based on your commentary about overall trends outside of Welding?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say very consistent. And you're seeing a little bit of seasonality in Q1 but if you look at the first quarter relative to the first quarter last year, really solid working capital performance and nothing unusual. And just look at the free cash flow nu
componenttext: I'd say very consistent. And you're seeing a little bit of seasonality in Q1 but if you look at the first quarter relative to the first quarter last year, really solid working capital performance and nothing unusual. And just look at the free cash flow number, 90%. The average is about last 3 years has been 65%. So really strong cash flow performance again in the first quarter. And keep in mind that we typically ramp up from here. So from a conversion standpoint, this is typically our lowest quarter. And then we'll go up sequentially as we go through the year, just typical seasonality. So nothing unusual in terms of working capital, continued strong performance.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from line of Stephen Volkmann from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from line of Stephen Volkmann from Jefferies.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, I think you mentioned that the best return that you can come up with, I'm paraphrasing here is basically incremental margin in organic growth. And I'm wondering if you've changed the way that you're thinking about that. And it seems like in 2017, w
componenttext: Scott, I think you mentioned that the best return that you can come up with, I'm paraphrasing here is basically incremental margin in organic growth. And I'm wondering if you've changed the way that you're thinking about that. And it seems like in 2017, we'll maybe will get a little less PLS headwind and maybe get a little organic growth. If we were to have a couple of points of organic growth in '17, my numbers, not yours, but how do you think about incrementals against that backdrop?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what I said was incremental profit from every dollar of incremental dollar of organic revenue was the highest value opportunity that we had and really what we are focused on leveraging to its full potential, not the percentage. We talked about incre
componenttext: Well, what I said was incremental profit from every dollar of incremental dollar of organic revenue was the highest value opportunity that we had and really what we are focused on leveraging to its full potential, not the percentage. We talked about incremental margin, so our target is roughly 35% going forward in terms of conversion to the bottom line from every incremental dollar of organic growth. That will vary up or down a little bit depending on the segment. And if anything, I would expect we would comfortably do better be or even a little bit better, given the elevated levels of profitability that we're now operating in.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Yvonne. Good morning, and welcome to ITW's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me this morning are our CEO, Scott Santi; and our CFO, Michael Larsen. During today's call, we will discuss our first quarter 2016 financial results and upda
componenttext:
Thank you, Yvonne. Good morning, and welcome to ITW's First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Joining me this morning are our CEO, Scott Santi; and our CFO, Michael Larsen. During today's call, we will discuss our first quarter 2016 financial results and update you on our 2016 earnings forecast.
Before we get to the results, let me remind you that this presentation contains our financial forecast for the 2016 second quarter and full year as well as other forward-looking statements identified on this slide. We refer you to the company's 2015 Form 10-K for more detail about important risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations.
Also, this presentation uses certain non-GAAP measures. While we use very few non-GAAP measures, a reconciliation of those non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measure is contained in the press release. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Aaron, and good morning. Overall, a pretty solid start to the year for ITW as we delivered solid near-term results and continued to make good progress in executing our strategy to position the company to deliver solid growth with best-in-class mar
componenttext:
Thanks, Aaron, and good morning. Overall, a pretty solid start to the year for ITW as we delivered solid near-term results and continued to make good progress in executing our strategy to position the company to deliver solid growth with best-in-class margins and returns.
In the quarter, we continued to deliver meaningful improvement on all of our key performance metrics. We grew EPS 7%, 10% excluding the impact of foreign currency translation. Organic growth came in at the midpoint of our forecast and was up 1%, 2% excluding the impact of our PLS initiatives. We improved operating margin by 120 basis points to 22.1% and increased the after-tax return on invested capital by 180 basis points to 21.2%. Both our operating margin and our ROIC metrics were new all-time first quarter highs for the company.
Free cash flow was also strong in the quarter at 90% of net income. Based on current demand trends and our strong operational and margin performance in the quarter, we are raising our GAAP EPS guidance for 2016 by $0.05 at the midpoint.
Before turning the call over to Michael for more detail on our Q1 results, I'd like to thank all of our ITW colleagues around the world for the great job that they continue to do in serving our customers and in executing our strategy. Michael, over to you.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everybody. As you saw this morning, ITW is off to a strong start in 2016 as the company delivered another solid quarter with excellent quality of earnings. GAAP EPS of $1.29 increased 7% versus prior year and exceeded t
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everybody. As you saw this morning, ITW is off to a strong start in 2016 as the company delivered another solid quarter with excellent quality of earnings. GAAP EPS of $1.29 increased 7% versus prior year and exceeded the midpoint of our guidance range by $0.04, driven by better operating margin as a result of strong operational execution on our Enterprise Initiatives.
Organic revenue was up 1% and in line with our guidance as North America grew 2% and International declined 1%. As Scott mentioned, we established a number of new all-time highs for our first quarter. Operating margin of 22.1% improved 120 points, with Strategic Sourcing, 80/20 Practice Excellence and business structure simplification, all contributing in a very meaningful way. Given the strong margin performance in the quarter, we now expect that operating margin will exceed 22.5% for the full year.
Operating income of $722 million was also a first quarter record. The prior record of $705 million was pre-enterprise strategy in 2012 and was achieved with revenues that were $1.3 billion higher than this quarter. 
After-tax ROIC was solid, free cash flow was strong, and we repurchased shares for $500 million. Just to comment on our external financial reporting. As you know, at ITW, we work hard to keep our external reporting simple, consistent and transparent. We only report one EPS number, and that is GAAP EPS. There are no adjusted EPS numbers. 
That said, let me just point out 2 items that are included in our first quarter GAAP EPS number of $1.29. First, foreign currency translation, which was right in line with our guidance assumption, an unfavorable $0.04 year-over-year. Second, last year's first quarter included a nonrecurring gain on the sale of a business. As a result, in the first quarter last year, other income was $21 million compared to $4 million this quarter. Excluding these 2 items, EPS would have increased 13%.
We strongly believe that in current economic environment and over the long term, our highly profitable and diversified portfolio is a core strength of the company. We are very well balanced in terms of our end market and geographic exposures and well positioned to perform at a high level across a wide range of economic scenarios.
Our consumer-facing businesses make up 60% of our revenues and include the Automotive OEM and Food Equipment segments as well as portions of Specialty Products and Construction. These businesses continue to deliver stable, high-quality growth. In the first quarter, our consumer-facing businesses were up 3% versus prior year and up 1%, sequentially. 
Our industrial-facing businesses, such as Welding and Test & Measurement and Electronics account for 40% of our revenues, and as expected, they declined year-over-year. As you can see, these businesses were down 3% but showed some improvement versus Q4 when they were down 6%. As you know, the year-over-year comparisons continue to ease as we go through the year.
1% organic revenue growth in the quarter, 2% excluding our Product Line Simplification initiatives or PLS. By region, North America was up 2%, with our consumer-facing businesses up 5%. Solid growth continues in Food Equipment, up 5%; Automotive, up 4%; and Construction products with Renovation/Remodeling, up 22%. 
Industrial-facing businesses were down 3%, with Welding down 7% and Test & Measurement and Electronics down 1%. On the international side, overall, down 1% with Europe, up 1% and Asia Pac, down 2%. Our international consumer businesses grew 1% and industrial is down 4%, primarily due to Welding.
In ITW, we believe that operating margin is a key indicator of our business's competitive advantage and the efficiency with which they leverage it. It is, in our view, a compelling indicator of the strength and competitiveness of ITW and is a key performance metric for every ITW business. 
In the first quarter, operating margin improved 120 basis points to 22.1% as 6 of our 7 segments improved. Construction Products increased 440 basis points; Specialty Products, 350 basis points; Food Equipment, 190 basis points; and Automotive was up 140 basis points, to mention a few. Approximately half of the decline in Welding this quarter is related to restructuring and other nonoperating items, and the team continues to do a good job in a challenging environment, as evidenced by the ability to sustain operating margins in the mid-20s despite a significant decline in revenue.
You can also see the positive impact of volume leverage in the faster growing segments, which gives you a sense of what margins and overall profitability will look like as organic growth picks up. On the right side of the page, we listed the drivers of our operating margin improvement this quarter, starting with 130 basis points from our self-help Enterprise Initiatives. Given the strong performance and positive momentum, we are now expecting more than 100 basis points from Enterprise Initiatives this year.
Price/cost came in as expected, stable and favorable at 20 basis points. The unfavorable 50 basis points in the other line is primarily related to investments in growth and overhead inflation. Overall, continued strong execution on Enterprise Initiatives and progress on delivering best-in-class margins consistently and sustainably.
Before we get into the segment results, we listed the quarterly progression on operating margin expansion since the first quarter of 2013: 520 basis point at the enterprise level; as you can see, Construction improved 930 basis points; 780 basis points in Food Equipment; and more than 600 basis points in Automotive and Specialty Products. Overall, good progress with more to come.
Turning to the segments. Automotive OEM had another strong quarter, with organic revenue up 3% and 26.4% operating margin. While 3% organic growth is a little below what we've seen out of our Automotive OEM segment over the last several quarters, the segment had a very tough comp, and Q1 revenue came in right where we planned it to be. 
In the first quarter of last year, the launch of several new programs in Europe resulted in revenue growth of 13% versus build of 2%, which is what created the tough comp for the business this year. Our long-term growth target for our Automotive OEM business remains 2 to 4 percentage points of above-market growth annually, and based on already sold programs and our new program pipeline, we expect to meet or exceed that target both in 2016 and for at least the next several years beyond.
In North America, 4% organic growth compares to auto build of up 5% and the Detroit 3, up 4%. China was up 6% in the quarter despite the fact that builds at Western OEMs were down slightly. As expected, operating margin improved 140 basis points to 26.4%, the highest in the company. 
A quick update on the acquisition of EF&C from ZF TRW that we announced last quarter. The acquisition remains on track and we expect the deal to close midyear. As a reminder, EF&C should be modestly accretive to EPS in the first 12 months, with accelerating benefits in 2017 and beyond.
Another strong quarter in Food Equipment, up 3% organically, with strength in North America, up 5% despite a challenging comparison. North America Equipment was up 5%, with strength in Refrigeration and Cooking and Service was up 4%. International was up 1%, with equipment, up 3% and service, flat. Continued strong margin performance as operating margin improved by 190 basis points to 24.5%. 
Test & Measurement and Electronics organic revenue down 2%. Test & Measurement, down 3% and Electronics, slightly better at down 1%. Sequentially, the segment was stable, down 7% compared to typical seasonality of down 6%.
Still a challenging external environment for our Welding business as organic revenue declined 9%. The 9% year-over-year decline breaks down as 5 points from oil and gas, 3 points from industrial and 1 point from commercial. North America was down 7%, with equipment, down 10% and consumables, down 1%. International was down 15%, primarily due to oil and gas. 
We saw some slowing sequentially, with demand trends down 3% compared to the typical 3% increase, and the team continues to take appropriate action on the cost side. As I mentioned earlier, approximately half of the operating margin decline in Welding this quarter is related to restructuring and other nonoperating items.
Polymers & Fluids achieved positive organic revenue growth of 1%. North America and International were both up 1% and Automotive Aftermarket improved 2%.
Strong quarter in Construction Products, as organic revenue increased 5%, with North America up 11%. Renovation/Remodeling was up 22%, Commercial was up 8% and Residential was up 2%. Asia Pacific was up 2% and Europe. Flat. Very strong progress in operating margin, up 440 basis points to 21%.
Solid quarter in Specialty Products, with organic revenue up 3%, with strength in our consumer packaging businesses. North America was up 5% and international was flat. And very strong progress on operating margin, with an increase of 350 basis points to 26.1%.
So for the year, based on our margin performance in the first quarter, we are raising our full year EPS guidance by $0.05 to a new range of $5.40 to $5.60. The $5.50 midpoint is 7% earnings growth. Our organic revenue  growth expectation of 1% to 3% is unchanged and in line with current run rates. 
We're forecasting that Enterprise Initiatives will deliver more than 100 basis points of margin improvement and that full year operating margin will exceed 22.5%. We still expect free cash flow conversion to exceed 100%, and we're targeting $2 billion in share repurchases. 
For the second quarter, our GAAP EPS guidance is $1.34 to $1.44, up 7% at the $1.39 midpoint. That puts 49% of our full year EPS forecast in the first half of the year, which is consistent with prior years. 
And with that, let me turn the call back to Aaron.

componenttext: Right. So you're heading down the right path here. So you have to look beyond just the euro. And maybe if you're heading down the path of EPS impact for the balance of the year, it is correct that based on current rates, as we sit here today, not just looking at the euro but the other currencies that we mentioned, if currency stays exactly where it is, things could turn out a little bit better. But as you know, there's a lot of volatility in currency. And so we have not included that in the numbers we gave you today --

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So my follow-up, I want to ask you and Scott, what do you think of the -- what do you make of the ISM? It's all that everyone seems to look at. And if you look at the new orders component, I mean, it's sort of telling you that a big "recovery" is on
componenttext: Okay. So my follow-up, I want to ask you and Scott, what do you think of the -- what do you make of the ISM? It's all that everyone seems to look at. And if you look at the new orders component, I mean, it's sort of telling you that a big "recovery" is on to come. Now last year was flashing green and manufacturing was going the other way. So I think I'm just trying to get your sense, you're a real-time company, short cycle, you're in the economy. Do you think that the ISM is reflecting, perhaps, some seasonal improvement, some sentiment improvement, only perhaps a little bit of systematic inventory restock? Or are you just seeing a complete disconnect? I just want -- again, focus on North America, please, and how do you, based on your years of experience, how do you interpret the ISM and why, frankly, would you be even more positive on your outlook?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've never -- from our particular lands, we've never viewed the ISM number as having a terrific correlation to conditions we're seeing on the ground. Certainly, not a way out, but I think from the standpoint of leading or lagging, it's not been particula
componenttext: We've never -- from our particular lands, we've never viewed the ISM number as having a terrific correlation to conditions we're seeing on the ground. Certainly, not a way out, but I think from the standpoint of leading or lagging, it's not been particularly reflective of the conditions that we're seeing. What I will tell you is my take on the quarter is that we saw pretty solid demand throughout. So I think things are relatively firm for right now. The one exception to that is obviously Welding. Hopefully, we're getting close to a bottom, but I can't say that we're seeing anything that tells us that. But beyond that, the overall demand profile inside the company was pretty solid as we move through the quarter, so no big movement and certainly, not any weakening as we move through the quarter.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I'd say it's been pretty firm. I think it's a little early in the quarter to call with one quarter's worth of data. But I think, again, in the aggregate, things were pretty solid through the quarter. Look at our consumer-facing businesses, where the overall demand rates have been pretty solid going back 4, 5 quarters now. I think we're feeling good about where we sit in the kind of the overall demand picture that we saw in the first quarter. That being said, it's still a pretty choppy environment out there. But there is no new worry beats based on our first quarter performance that we saw across the company.

componenttext: Yes. So I think we talked about a tough comp in the first quarter due to the new programs launched in Europe. And if you recall, Europe, last year, was up 11% on builds of 1%. So that comp will be with us for the year. But in terms of the year-over-year organic growth rate, as we sit here today, looking at the typical seasonality, Q1 is the low point for the year, and the organic growth rate on a year-over-year basis will improve as we go through the year.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And maybe my follow-on question, moving on to Welding. So clearly, part of the portfolio, there's been a little bit more challenge. You guys mentioned half of the margin performance this quarter was related to restructuring actions. Does that
componenttext: Okay, great. And maybe my follow-on question, moving on to Welding. So clearly, part of the portfolio, there's been a little bit more challenge. You guys mentioned half of the margin performance this quarter was related to restructuring actions. Does that start to tail off as we progress through the year? Or how are you thinking about that business? So I guess clearly, on the face of it, when you take a look at the decremental margins, the decremental margins in the first quarter were pretty high. Just trying to get a sense for how that business will traject for the rest of the year.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we had, as you said, about half of the impact in the first quarter here, the margin declined -- down 9%, which is pretty significant, organic. About half of that was restructuring related. We expect a similar impact here in Q2 and then improvement
componenttext: Yes, so we had, as you said, about half of the impact in the first quarter here, the margin declined -- down 9%, which is pretty significant, organic. About half of that was restructuring related. We expect a similar impact here in Q2 and then improvement in the second half of the year on the margin side. And obviously, the comparisons get significantly easier in the back half of the year. So last year, in the first quarter, Welding was down 3%, which sounds like an easy comp, but actually, it's not when you look at how the rest of 2015 unfolded. So the comps will get better as we go through this year. Based on current sequential trends that we look at, we'll see flat to positive in the back half. And margins will improve also in the back half. We have another slug of restructuring to get through here in the second quarter and then for now, hopefully, the worst is behind us.

componenttext: Okay, good. Moving on to Construction. Construction was a standout this quarter, with 5% and 11% in North America. componenttext: Yes. The answer to your first question is there's really no way to factor weather in, in terms of how it might have impacted our results relative to whatever you might call a normalized year. So -- which is a big reason why we usually don't bite on any single quarter trends in construction as predictive or indicative of overall demand. I think what I would say is we certainly exited the quarter in pretty good shape there, so I think we're not seeing anything slow down or ease up. And we'll hope it continues through the balance of the year for sure.

componenttext: Okay, great. And just a quick follow-on on Construction. Europe is flat and we're seeing some signs of maybe green shoots and construction activity in Europe.
