Welding's obviously got some macro issues, maybe those comps ease but can you just help us [indiscernible] to flesh it out for our own

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, I mean, as Scott said, this is really a process that's being orchestrated at the divisional level. So we have 84 divisions. At the end of last year, 60% of our revenues were in that ready-to-grow category. And we look at the progress every qua
componenttext: Yes, David, I mean, as Scott said, this is really a process that's being orchestrated at the divisional level. So we have 84 divisions. At the end of last year, 60% of our revenues were in that ready-to-grow category. And we look at the progress every quarter and we are on track to get to the 85% ready-to-grow. So most of the company will be in a position to accelerate organic growth going into '17. And it's a gradual time line. So every month, every quarter, divisions reach that stage of being ready to grow. And that's -- at the segment level, we have different levels of progress based on when the segments really start to focus on the organic growth strategy. And so it's hard to really comment at the segment and end market level beyond what we just walked you through.

componenttext: I don't think I would -- given what we're seeing, I would certainly not call it a floor, right? So I think we got to see what the future holds there a little bit. But our planning assumption is, I think, sufficiently conservative in terms of its impact in the overall forecast for the back half of the year. But it's still a pretty choppy environment, and Michael gave you some numbers before and down at 15% year-on-year in industrial and oil and gas, 6 quarters in here. It's still pretty challenging.

componenttext: Yes, understand. And then just switching to price/cost as a follow-on. 20 bps relatively modest. Maybe -- could you just may be decompose that between price and [indiscernible] And the reason why is that obviously we got steel inflation coming through in the next 6 to 9 months. And I'm wondering how we should think about that price/cost gap developing.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Nigel, price/cost came in as expected as you pointed out and slightly favorable 20 basis points again. And as you know, maybe different for some other companies price/cost has not been a significant margin driver over the last 3 years. And I think
componenttext: Yes. So Nigel, price/cost came in as expected as you pointed out and slightly favorable 20 basis points again. And as you know, maybe different for some other companies price/cost has not been a significant margin driver over the last 3 years. And I think what's going on inside the businesses is really with the support from our Strategic Sourcing team, the businesses are closely monitoring the material cost side and taking appropriate action on the price side. And on both price and material costs, we've not seen any significant impact or any change in terms of the results in the second quarter. And so going forward, we remain confident that we can continue to generate this type of modest price/cost variability on a go-forward basis.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: So Test & Measurement and Electronics, you're trying to grow for the first time, I think, mid-2014. How much of the improvement is the markets getting better versus easier comparison versus ITW's specific focus on [indiscernible] to grow. Probably say all 3 but if there's any additional color what is going on in that segment, that would be helpful. And have you seen any increase in capital equipment on the Test & Measurement side and Electronics with 6% [ph] you mentioned the strength in semis. doesn't seem like a pretty strong result versus what you can see.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the -- we haven't characterized it as things pretty stable on the Test & Measurement side but no big or even modest improvement in terms of underlying activity but certainly a solid stable performance. And on the Electronics side, as we talke
componenttext: Yes, I think the -- we haven't characterized it as things pretty stable on the Test & Measurement side but no big or even modest improvement in terms of underlying activity but certainly a solid stable performance. And on the Electronics side, as we talked about, some nice sequential improvement in the 2 sectors that you referenced. I think we want to see another quarter or 2 before we decide that, that's a long-term trend. But overall, it's a nice improvement.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful, Scott. And maybe -- I mean, you've obviously done very well versus of enterprise strategy goals that you set now really several years ago. How do we think about -- it's a tough organic growth environment in '16 again. But the one goa
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful, Scott. And maybe -- I mean, you've obviously done very well versus of enterprise strategy goals that you set now really several years ago. How do we think about -- it's a tough organic growth environment in '16 again. But the one goal that's out there, you doing 20 basis points better than global industrial production still seems a little hard to achieve as Welding continues to be weak. How do you look at that goal here over the next couple of years? Do you need Welding to improve? Can you do it still be if the other things are good? How do you look at that goal?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if Welding continues to strengthen 11% a quarter, it's certainly going to be a tough nut to crack. But clearly, that's not our expectation. I don't think it would be his expectation. That's -- that whole industry is a core part of the indust
componenttext: Well, I think if Welding continues to strengthen 11% a quarter, it's certainly going to be a tough nut to crack. But clearly, that's not our expectation. I don't think it would be his expectation. That's -- that whole industry is a core part of the industrial economy around the world. We have a terrific position in it. We're certainly sort of a double whammy right now oil and gas and slow industrial investment, but all that's creating a lot of pent-up demand at the same time as things slowing around in our [indiscernible] and Welding this coming out of the sort of down cycles in the market. There's a 8- to 12-quarter run some really strong recovery. I don't think there's anything fundamental that's changed in our view terms of the overall attractiveness of the Welding market. And so I think in general, what I would point to in terms of -- in our conviction in terms of our goal. We have to save this portfolio so that we are operating in spaces everywhere with product really matters to the customer as long as we continue to generate solutions that help our customers serve their customers better, that we've got plenty of room to outgrow the underlying economy. And we're not stepping off of that one bit in terms of both our commitment to all the offer it's going on inside the company to make that happen.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Deane Dray from RBC.
componenttext: Next question is from Deane Dray from RBC.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to circle back on EF&C. And so more specifics on the business now that you own it. And Scott, you called out some new platforms. We interested in hearing just broadly what the new platforms are, the adjacencies. And then maybe where might there b
componenttext: I wanted to circle back on EF&C. And so more specifics on the business now that you own it. And Scott, you called out some new platforms. We interested in hearing just broadly what the new platforms are, the adjacencies. And then maybe where might there be overlaps where you going to bring in Product Line Simplification and maybe what percent that might be versus the revenue base today.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, not a lot of overlap. That's one of the attractive things about it both from a product line and a customer -- from a product line and a customer standpoint. In terms of the complementary platforms, it probably gets a little too messy to try to get in
componenttext: Yes, not a lot of overlap. That's one of the attractive things about it both from a product line and a customer -- from a product line and a customer standpoint. In terms of the complementary platforms, it probably gets a little too messy to try to get into too much detail. Let me just say that they are similar to the current platforms we are in, and that they are highly sort of value-added engineered solutions to specific OEM customer needs, some different categories in terms of the actual functionality but largely similar types of positions that we have in our core business. So lots of opportunity to add those categories to the existing categories we have. I think what I would say is we will clearly spend some time on this in December. And it would be more effective for us to do so then as we've had a couple of quarters with the business under our belt. From the standpoint of PLS, certainly, my expectation is that we're going to have a fair amount of it there under our normal application of 80/20. Less so related to dealing with overlap. As I said, it's not a big issue. But we need to -- we have some initial based on some of our due diligence, but we certainly need some time to get in there over the next couple of quarters, and we'll look at it in a much more fulsome way. But it'll be part of the mix for a while, part of the margin improvement agenda there.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then what about the margin goals that you've laid out, basically double margins by year 5? Have you thought through, can you share what that progression might be? I would imagine the gains come more in the back half of that time frame as oppose
componenttext: Great. And then what about the margin goals that you've laid out, basically double margins by year 5? Have you thought through, can you share what that progression might be? I would imagine the gains come more in the back half of that time frame as opposed to being linear.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I would say probably play a little more linear in sort of our typical integration. This is -- as we talked before, the application of 80/20 is in a quick fix. It's a 3- to 5-year process from go to full integration. And I would say again, we'll have a
componenttext: No, I would say probably play a little more linear in sort of our typical integration. This is -- as we talked before, the application of 80/20 is in a quick fix. It's a 3- to 5-year process from go to full integration. And I would say again, we'll have a better view of what we'll be able to get done in '17 on this when we are a couple of quarters down the road. But I think in general, I would -- I think a more appropriate planning assumption would be a couple of points a year for the next 5 [ph] and a big hockey stick.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just as a follow-up. One of the things within the Food Equipment results today, I was surprised to see service not a little bit better, given the kind of focus that you put on it there. Was there anything in the quarter that might have be
componenttext: Got it. And then just as a follow-up. One of the things within the Food Equipment results today, I was surprised to see service not a little bit better, given the kind of focus that you put on it there. Was there anything in the quarter that might have been a drag there? Should we start seeing service become a more meaningful contributor?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer to the second question is absolutely. I think some of the problems with these quarterly -- with these quarterly calibrations are these are strategies that play out over the course of the year. So you got a lot of things bouncing around. I don't
componenttext: The answer to the second question is absolutely. I think some of the problems with these quarterly -- with these quarterly calibrations are these are strategies that play out over the course of the year. So you got a lot of things bouncing around. I don't -- sitting here right now, I can't say whether there's sort of what the top profile was in service in Food Equipment. But in general, as you said, we've got a lot of focus on service. It's a great business and a great competitive advantage for us. The other thing is that there is some PLS of a couple of parts of that business going on right now, but my assumption is I have to like deeper but our assumption is probably had some impact in Q2.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Next question is from Mr. Mig Dobre from Baird.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: If I may, just going back to the broader organic growth questions from earlier. Just kind of looking at the quarter here, EMEA certainly ended up outgrowing all the regions, 3% versus everywhere else growth at 1% or below. And I'm just wondering from your perspective looking into back half of the year, do you still expect this kind of leadership from EMEA? Or are you thinking that we're going to see acceleration from North America deliver those organic growth goals of years?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if you look at the first half growth rates both international and North America, kind of in the low single digits, that's probably a good way to think about the back half of the year. So we certainly don't expect any acceleration on a regiona
componenttext: Yes. I think if you look at the first half growth rates both international and North America, kind of in the low single digits, that's probably a good way to think about the back half of the year. So we certainly don't expect any acceleration on a regional basis. And as you know, we don't run the company that way.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe again going back to Food Equipment. Can you provide any commentary in terms of what's been driving the growth in equipment? I'm wondering if there's anything to differentiate in terms of washing versus cooking, refrigeration. Any colo
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe again going back to Food Equipment. Can you provide any commentary in terms of what's been driving the growth in equipment? I'm wondering if there's anything to differentiate in terms of washing versus cooking, refrigeration. Any color there would be helpful.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I made some comments earlier really that this was broad-based strength on -- in terms of the product lines, with refrigeration, warewash cooking, the retail side, the scales, overall really strong performance across the board. But as you heard, equip
componenttext: Yes, I made some comments earlier really that this was broad-based strength on -- in terms of the product lines, with refrigeration, warewash cooking, the retail side, the scales, overall really strong performance across the board. But as you heard, equipment up 9% in North America.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would characterize much more a function of a significant part of our Food Equipment business reaching that ready-to-grow stage. They've been there for the last year or so and just being in a position to be much more aggressive in terms of attacking
componenttext: And I would characterize much more a function of a significant part of our Food Equipment business reaching that ready-to-grow stage. They've been there for the last year or so and just being in a position to be much more aggressive in terms of attacking their growth opportunities. The innovation pipeline there is terrific. That certainly is contributing, but it's more of an end product of all the work that we've done to get the portfolio right, get the business simplified and get it focused on its best growth opportunities.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And I appreciate that but obviously, the drivers are, I presume, a little bit different warewashing versus cooking, right?
componenttext: Right. And I appreciate that but obviously, the drivers are, I presume, a little bit different warewashing versus cooking, right?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think -- I wouldn't say they are a lot different based on what I just said. We've got a highly competitive, highly differentiated product line with great opportunity to grow and are now in a position to really focus on attacking that.
componenttext: I don't think -- I wouldn't say they are a lot different based on what I just said. We've got a highly competitive, highly differentiated product line with great opportunity to grow and are now in a position to really focus on attacking that.

componenttext: A question kind of going back to pricing. I know as you just said, Scott, the company focuses on differentiated product and that kind of shields ITW from price competition. But we are seeing some evidence of competitive pricing in some of the markets that you really don't participate in directly. componenttext: Yes, I really don't want to get into too much detail here, but in terms of Q3 versus Q4, we're just getting going here, Andy. What I can tell you is for the second half, based on what we know today, we expect it to be neutral. And I don't think it'll be a big swing on a quarterly basis but I don't know that for sure yet.

componenttext: Yes. So I think China overall was flat, with strong performance in Automotive, auto up 13%. Test & Measurement fairly solid, low single-digit growth. headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up maybe this time, you made a comment earlier about PLS being less in 2017. But I guess, that means it's not going to go away. Does it ever go away? Is it -- does it go to a normal level? I mean, how do we think about the cadence of the PLS lon
componenttext: My follow-up maybe this time, you made a comment earlier about PLS being less in 2017. But I guess, that means it's not going to go away. Does it ever go away? Is it -- does it go to a normal level? I mean, how do we think about the cadence of the PLS longer term?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think eventually, it goes down to a level what I described as normal maintenance, probably less than 0.5% a year. I think -- I don't want to get too specific here because as Michael said with the [indiscernible] cycle, but the big load of activity on th
componenttext: I think eventually, it goes down to a level what I described as normal maintenance, probably less than 0.5% a year. I think -- I don't want to get too specific here because as Michael said with the [indiscernible] cycle, but the big load of activity on this for the company over the last 3 years-plus has really been around the portfolio strategy execution. Once we get it to where we want it, it's certainly become something that we do some minor on an annual basis, but it's not something we even talk about anymore at that point and maybe that's a couple of years out from here.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great, that's helpful. And then just on restructuring, I wonder, do you have additional restructuring in your plan for 3Q, 4Q? And maybe if you can just touch on sort of what you're doing there and how we should think about that impact in '17.
componenttext: Okay. Great, that's helpful. And then just on restructuring, I wonder, do you have additional restructuring in your plan for 3Q, 4Q? And maybe if you can just touch on sort of what you're doing there and how we should think about that impact in '17.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Steve, our restructuring assumption for the year in that $60 million to $70 million range is unchanged. And we don't expect any significant changes to that as we go through the Q3 and Q4. Given current levels of demand, we're at $60 million to $70
componenttext: Yes. So Steve, our restructuring assumption for the year in that $60 million to $70 million range is unchanged. And we don't expect any significant changes to that as we go through the Q3 and Q4. Given current levels of demand, we're at $60 million to $70 million and don't see anything right now that would take it outside of that range.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Just 2 quick follow-ups. One, I know you don't want to comment on the auto acquisition, but I guess, on your other businesses as we exit 2016, how should we think about amortization expense from acquisitions because I would assume that's another tailwind as we think about '17 versus '16. And then another clarification just on FX impact to EPS. I think last quarter, you guided to $0.20. Did you change that number with the pound?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start with the last one. I think the $0.20 you're referring to was way back when at the beginning of the year. There's a lot of volatility, as you know, on the currency side of things. And so while at current rates, we'd expect it to be less t
componenttext: Yes, let me start with the last one. I think the $0.20 you're referring to was way back when at the beginning of the year. There's a lot of volatility, as you know, on the currency side of things. And so while at current rates, we'd expect it to be less than $0.20, it's really hard to put a hard and fast number out there, given all the volatility. On the intangible amortization, we expect that to continue to go down. The 2 segments where we talked about this, Test & Measurement and Polymers & Fluids, it's maybe something like 30 to 50 basis points of favorability on an annual basis in those 2 segments so...

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Steve Fisher from UBS.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Q3 margin guidance implies a moderating of the year-over-year improvement in margins even if you adjust for the 50 basis points of EF&C. It doesn't sound like there's a lot more restructuring there. Are we just sort of getting to the maturity point of
componenttext: The Q3 margin guidance implies a moderating of the year-over-year improvement in margins even if you adjust for the 50 basis points of EF&C. It doesn't sound like there's a lot more restructuring there. Are we just sort of getting to the maturity point of the margin improvement or is there perhaps some conservatism there?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's certainly not, I think we're getting to a level of maturity here. So as you know, we have guided to 100 basis points of margin expansion this year and in '17, independent of volume. And Scott talked a little bit about how much more potential we still
componenttext: It's certainly not, I think we're getting to a level of maturity here. So as you know, we have guided to 100 basis points of margin expansion this year and in '17, independent of volume. And Scott talked a little bit about how much more potential we still have inside the company. Really the last year, if you'll recall, margins were up 180 basis points. We had a really strong third quarter last year, and so it's really more of a comp issue than anything else.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then how have your expectations changed for the industrial-facing businesses year-over-year? Last quarter, I think you said there was maybe a chance that you could get to neutral exiting the year. Has Welding now kind of taken a
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then how have your expectations changed for the industrial-facing businesses year-over-year? Last quarter, I think you said there was maybe a chance that you could get to neutral exiting the year. Has Welding now kind of taken a step backwards there? Or how are you thinking about that sort of consumer versus industrial by kind of exiting the year?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think I'd just go back to what I said earlier. I think Welding, given the performance in the first 2 quarters, the contraction is certainly continuing on longer than expectation is kind of a funny word because we tend to just react to the conditio
componenttext: Well, I think I'd just go back to what I said earlier. I think Welding, given the performance in the first 2 quarters, the contraction is certainly continuing on longer than expectation is kind of a funny word because we tend to just react to the conditions that we're seeing. But I think ultimately, heading into the year, given the kind of decline we saw last year, I think we're hopeful that things were going to flatten out by the back half. Clearly, given the first 2 quarters, that's not the case, but at some point, it's going to happen. And I think what we're doing in the short run is managing the cost structure with some restructuring actions and other things we're doing to do what we should be doing in the short term while preserving our position in our markets and certainly being ready to participate fully as things turn around up there. So I don't -- but at the same token, we're performing better, our margins were certainly offsetting -- more than offsetting the impact that Welding's having on the short term, and that's one of the values of a portfolio of 7 really strong businesses is we're never probably going to have all 7 going 100% in the right direction all at the same time, but we're going to have enough of them around the overall enterprise performance in whatever environment, this is going to be pretty darn good.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Next question is from Walter Liptak from Seaport Global.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Wanted to ask about the Food Equipment business and the 300 basis points of margin improvement. And if there's a way of measuring how much of that was 80/20 Enterprise Initiatives and how much was volume-related.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the best detail and the most detail that we give you, Walter, is in the appendix and the press release. And so if you look at food, total margin expansion, 300 basis points, 110 of that was from operating leverage. Similar to what you saw in Q1, as t
componenttext: Yes, the best detail and the most detail that we give you, Walter, is in the appendix and the press release. And so if you look at food, total margin expansion, 300 basis points, 110 of that was from operating leverage. Similar to what you saw in Q1, as these businesses begin to accelerate growth, you see really nice improvement on the margin side as a result. And then in addition, approximately 80 basis points of Enterprise Initiatives and other margin expansion. And then restructuring was slightly lower this year versus the second quarter last year. And so we break that out in the press release by segment and total ITW.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. Great, okay. And then just as a follow-up on the EF&C business. The doubling in margin, and it's been a while since you guys have done an acquisition like this. So wonder how much of this is new programs related to the business management sy
componenttext: Okay, got it. Great, okay. And then just as a follow-up on the EF&C business. The doubling in margin, and it's been a while since you guys have done an acquisition like this. So wonder how much of this is new programs related to the business management system and, if at all, you're thinking this is sort of like a new, like a test case for future acquisitions.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't characterize it as a test case. I think our track record, even though it has been a while, I don't think we've forgotten how to do this. We have, in many ways, been doing this, everything we're going to do in the EF&C and all 84 of our other di
componenttext: I wouldn't characterize it as a test case. I think our track record, even though it has been a while, I don't think we've forgotten how to do this. We have, in many ways, been doing this, everything we're going to do in the EF&C and all 84 of our other divisions over the last couple of years, which is front to back reapplying our 80/20 management system. So I think our methodology is inside the company is extremely well defined, extremely well proven. We have a parallel business running at mid-20s EBIT margins that we're in. I don't think there's any sort of mystery about what we need to do in the process where getting used to make it happen.

And so that portion is done. And the comment was that the $800 million, the balance that takes us to $2 billion, that's really more of -- think of that is a more normal run rate for the company. headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, May. Good morning, and welcome to ITW's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I am Michael Larsen, ITW's SVP and CFO, and joining me this morning is our Chairman and CEO, Scott Santi. During today's call, we will discuss our second quarter 2016
componenttext:
Thank you, May. Good morning, and welcome to ITW's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I am Michael Larsen, ITW's SVP and CFO, and joining me this morning is our Chairman and CEO, Scott Santi. During today's call, we will discuss our second quarter 2016 financial results and update you on our 2016 earnings forecast. Following our comments, we will be happy to take your questions. [Operator Instructions] 
Before we get to the results, let me remind you that this presentation contains our financial forecast for the 2016 third quarter and full year as well as other forward-looking statements identified on this slide. We refer you to the company's 2015 Form 10-K and Form 10-Q for the first quarter of 2016 for more detail about important risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations.
Also, this presentation uses certain non-GAAP measures. While we use very few non-GAAP measures, a reconciliation of those non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures is contained in the press release. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael, and good morning. Overall, we were very pleased with our second quarter performance as we continued to execute well and, as a result, delivered strong results and set several new all-time performance records for the company. EPS of $1.46
componenttext:
Thanks, Michael, and good morning. Overall, we were very pleased with our second quarter performance as we continued to execute well and, as a result, delivered strong results and set several new all-time performance records for the company. EPS of $1.46 was up 12% year-on-year and came in $0.07 above the midpoint of our guidance, $0.04 from better margins, $0.01 from slightly higher revenue and $0.02 from nonoperating items largely related to our minority ownership interest in our former Decorative Surfaces segment.
Operating income of $792 million was up 8% year-on-year and was the highest quarterly operating income in the company's history. Q2 operating margins of 23.1% were up 180 basis points, and after-tax ROIC improved 260 basis points to 22.9%, both of which were all-time records for the company. 
As I commented in our Q2 earnings release, these record results reinforce our conviction in the performance potential of ITW's business model and reflect directly on the great progress that our people around the world continued to make in positioning the company to leverage it to its full potential. While we have made significant progress in this regard over the last 3.5 years, we see plenty of opportunity for further improvement ahead.
I am also pleased with the progress that we are making in our transition to focusing on accelerating organic growth. Organic growth, excluding PLS impact of 2% at the enterprise level, was pretty solid in this environment, particularly when factoring in the 11% decline in our Welding segment in the quarter. 
All 6 of our other segments delivered positive year-on-year organic growth in Q2. Net of Welding and PLS impacts, organic growth for our 6 other segments combined was 4% in the quarter. On a year-to-date basis, our 2016 organic growth rate has improved by 130 basis points versus full year 2015 despite significant further erosion in welding demand and tough first half comps in our auto OEM segment. 
A couple of final comments before I turn the call back to Michael. First, earlier this month, we completed the acquisition of the Engineered Fasteners and Components business from ZF TRW. This is a great addition to the company, and I would like to publicly welcome the 3,500-plus members of the EF&C team to ITW. And second, I would like to once again thank all of my ITW colleagues around the world for the great job that they continued to do in serving our customers and executing our strategy with excellence. 
Michael?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everybody. Once again, ITW delivered another strong quarter with high quality of earnings, and solid execution in improving growth performance in many parts of the company drove record results. We grew GAAP EPS 12% to $
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning, everybody. Once again, ITW delivered another strong quarter with high quality of earnings, and solid execution in improving growth performance in many parts of the company drove record results. We grew GAAP EPS 12% to $1.46 and exceeded the midpoint of our guidance range.
Organic revenue was up 2% gross, 1% when including PLS, with fairly stable demand globally and improving organic growth focus and performance across the company. Good progress in Q2, with 6 of 7 segments achieving positive organic growth, with Welding the only exception. And in Q2 of last year, 3 out of 7 segments were growing organically. 
Consumer-facing businesses were up 3%, industrial-facing down 2%, no material change from Q1. On a regional basis, North America was up 0.4%, EMEA up 2.9%, APAC up 1% and China was up 0.4%. 
A comment on the U.K., which represents 5% of ITW sales. In Q2, our U.K. sales were up 2%, with no signs of a slowdown. And in our opinion, it is too early to tell what the longer-term impact from Brexit may be, but at current FX rates, the weakening of the British pound is modestly unfavorable, which is factored into our updated guidance.
As Scott mentioned, we established new all-time records on a number of our key performance metrics. Operating margin of 23.1%, up 180 basis points versus last year. Enterprise Initiatives contributed 120 basis points to margin expansion, with price/cost and volume leverage and other contributing to the remaining 60 basis points. We grew operating income 8% to $792 million, making this the most profitable quarter ever in ITW's history.
After-tax ROIC improved 260 basis points and was also a new all-time record at 22.9%. We invested about $140 million in our businesses for growth and productivity. Free cash flow of $471 million was up 23% versus Q2 of last year and 90% to a net income conversion that was consistent with typical Q2 seasonality. 
In the second quarter, we allocated $500 million to share repurchases and plan to repurchase an additional $1 billion in the second half, bringing the total for the full year to approximately $2 billion, with $1.2 billion from overseas funds and about $800 million from normal surplus cash flow. 
In the second quarter, ITW operating margin exceeded 23% for the first time. And we listed the margin drivers on the right side of the page, starting with 120 basis points from our Enterprise Initiatives. Price/cost came in as expected, modestly favorable, 20 basis points; and volume leverage and other contributed the balance.
Continued strong margin expansion across the company, with Construction Products up 440 basis points to 24.3%; Food Equipment up 300 basis points to 25%; Specialty Products, Test & Measurement and Electronics both up 250 basis points; and Automotive up 130 basis points to 25.8%.
Polymers & Fluids was flat due to restructuring. And in Welding, despite 140 basis points of restructuring impact this quarter, operating margin was 24.9%. Welding's peak-to-trough revenues are now down approximately 20% and yet operating margins are still solid in the mid-20s. This performance over a pretty challenging cycle is a good example of the resilience of the ITW business model.
Turning to the segment discussion, and starting with Automotive OEM. Another solid quarter, with organic revenue up 4% against a tough comparison last year, as Scott mentioned earlier. In North America, 3% organic growth. Europe was up 8%, and China was up 13% despite the fact that overall builds were only up 4% and flat at Western OEMs. We expect growth rates to continue to improve in the second half as comparisons get a little easier.
Another very solid quarter in Food Equipment, up 5% organically, with broad-based strength on the equipment side, including refrigeration, warewash, cooking and scales. North America was up 6% despite a tough comparison, with equipment up 9%, driven by end-market demand in K-12 [ph], lodging, health care and retail, and service was up 1%. International was up 3%, with equipment up 4% and service up 2%. And continued strong margin performance as volume leverage and savings from Enterprise Initiatives improved operating margin by 300 basis points to 25%.
Also a very solid quarter for Test & Measurement and Electronics as organic revenue grew 3%. The Electronics platform grew 6% due to end-market strength in solar and semiconductor. We've talked about the margin expansion potential in this segment before, and we are pleased to see 250 basis points of improvement to 18.6%. And remember that the 18.6% includes 370 basis points of acquisition-related, noncash amortization charges, which will beat up over time. 
Declines in Welding demand continued in Q2, with organic revenue down 11% in the quarter, with equipment down 13% and consumables down 10%. The decline breaks down as 5 points from oil and gas; 5 points from industrial, which is mostly heavy equipment related to agriculture infrastructure and mining; and 1 point from commercial. North America was down 8%, with equipment down 10% and consumables down 5%. International was down 21%, again, due largely to oil and gas. If demand holds steady at current levels, year-on-year percentage declines should moderate in the back half of 2016 due to easier comps. And like I said earlier, solid operating margin performance of 24.9%, which includes 140 basis points of restructuring impact.
Polymers & Fluids delivered another quarter of positive organic revenue growth, up 2%, as this segment continues its pivot to growth after an extensive period of PLS process over the last 3-plus years. On a regional basis, North America was up 1% and international was up 3%.
Approximately half of the segment revenues are related to Automotive Aftermarket, which grew 3%. The balance is primarily industrial MRO applications as Fluids improved 1% and Polymers was flat. Overall margins were unchanged at 20.9%, which includes 70 basis points of restructuring impact. As with our Test & Measurement and Electronics segment, 20.9% includes 420 basis points of acquisition-related noncash amortization charges.
Another solid quarter in Construction Products, as organic revenue increased 3%. North America was down 1%, with a tough year-over-year comparison of 15% in Q2 last year. Renovation/Remodeling was down 6% after being up 22% in the first quarter. And in the quarter, North America -- in North America, commercial was up 5% and residential up 1%. And overall, we feel like we're exiting the quarter in good shape from a demand perspective. 
On the last call, we talked about how quarterly numbers in construction can be a little choppy and not necessarily a good indicator of overall levels of demand. To normalize trends, if you look at North America in the first half up 4%, Renovation/Remodel up 6%, commercial up 7% and residential up 2%, you get a more accurate picture of the underlying levels of demand, which are pretty solid.
Asia Pacific was up 7% due to Australia. Europe was up 6%, driven by the U.K. up 7%, France up 6% and Germany up 10%. And again, very strong progress in operating margin, up 440 basis points to 24.3%. 
Finally, another solid quarter in Specialty Products, with organic revenue flat. Solid growth in consumer packaging offset by some lumpiness on the equipment side. And very good progress on operating margin with an increase of 250 basis points to 26%.
Turning to EF&C. We are very pleased to complete this terrific acquisition on July 1. As you know, in the Automotive OEM space, with ITW's very focused strategic positioning, we've demonstrated the ability to outgrow global auto builds by over 400 basis points on average since 2012. And given the visibility that we have in this business, we are confident that we can continue to outgrow auto builds by 200 to 400 basis points over the next several years.
We are excited about adding EF&C to ITW because it gives us some additional leverage on this very focused strategy and broadens our ability to serve and grow with our global and regional Automotive OEM and tier [ph] customers. It expands our ability to drive our global content per vehicle and increase our share of the relevant market. 
For reference, our global content of $30 per vehicle compares to a relevant market that is greater than $200 per vehicle. Specifically, EF&C adds a number of things to our current position. First of all, it adds several new strategic differentiated product platforms that have similar characteristics to the core product platforms that we support today. And on a regional basis, with its global, strategically located manufacturing facilities, it is very complementary to our geographic footprint, which is a little more weighted towards North America. So it gives us better global balance overall. 
And certainly, we continue to see significant potential to leverage our 80/20 business management process and help the EF&C team continue to improve its operating metrics. Operating margin entering ITW are about 10%, and we're confident that we have a clear path to doubling that rate, at a minimum, over the next 5 years. EF&C already has a very experienced and capable operating team, with a reputation for delivering reliable quality and excellent customer service performance. 
From the standpoint of the transaction and the financial components, purchase price of $450 million is less than 1x sales, and the business is actually performing slightly better than expected. The 2016 financial impact is $220 million to $240 million of revenues, so $110 million to $120 million in Q3 and in Q4. 
From a margin standpoint, EF&C is dilutive approximately 50 basis points to ITW operating margin and after-tax ROIC, and dilutive approximately 200 basis points to the Automotive OEM segment. So to be clear, excluding EF&C, we would have guided to approximately 23% operating margin for the full year-to-date. Including EF&C, we are maintaining our prior guidance of greater than 22.5%.
From an EPS standpoint, we expect no impact in 2016 due to typical acquisition accounting-related impacts but certainly accretive in 2017. And we're confident that we can generate after-tax returns in the mid- to high teens by year 7.
Last page, our updated guidance for 2016 assumes current foreign exchange rates and includes the acquisition of EF&C. We're raising full year GAAP EPS guidance by $0.10 at the midpoint to a new range of $5.50 to $5.70. The $5.60 midpoint represents 9% earnings growth on a year-over-year basis. 
We expect that demand remains stable at current levels, and as a result, we're narrowing our full year organic growth forecast to 1% to 2% due to the more challenging-than-expected market conditions in Welding. Consistent with prior forecast, our guidance includes approximately 1 percentage point of PLS impact. So excluding PLS, we expect full year organic revenue growth of 2% to 3%. 
Keep in mind that while PLS does reduce revenues in the short term, it is both a critical driver of our margin performance and a key component of our portfolio management strategy as we exit slower-growth product lines and focus on our most compelling opportunities to accelerate organic growth at ITW-caliber margins.
As I said earlier, our operating margin guidance is unchanged at greater than 22.5% but now includes approximately 50 basis points of dilution from EF&C. We're maintaining our previously communicated target of $2 billion in share repurchases for the year. And finally, for the third quarter, our GAAP EPS guidance including EF&C is $1.42 to $1.52, assuming operating margin of approximately 23% and 1% to 3% organic growth. 
So that concludes our prepared remarks. We will now open up the call to your questions. Please be brief. [Operator Instructions]

componenttext: The expectation through the balance of the year on the revenue side for Welding at current demand rates is we're down mid-single digits in Q3 and Q4. That's slightly -- the rate is better because of the comps get easier, but we're -- in our scenario, based on what we're seeing right now, we're still expecting some further decline. From the standpoint of the incremental margins, they should be certainly right in line. Some of the benefits from the restructuring charges that we incurred in Q2  should start to show up in Q3 and Q4.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. So shifting gears, I appreciate your comments on the U.K. I think other companies have more or less said it's still too early to say anything. It's hard from our perspective -- I mean, generically, our perspective to surmise why Europe doesn't
componenttext: All right. So shifting gears, I appreciate your comments on the U.K. I think other companies have more or less said it's still too early to say anything. It's hard from our perspective -- I mean, generically, our perspective to surmise why Europe doesn't suffer some sort of economic deferral or confidence issues. Certainly, you can see European investors rotating into U.S. stocks, and then it clearly concerned, right? My question, you guys have a lot of European exposure relative to other industrial companies. What -- you've done a fantastic job, and you -- clearly, I think people see the flex in your business model, but I can't imagine you're complacent, right? So I'm trying to understand, what is your strategy for managing through what could be possibly deteriorating fundamentals in Europe? And as the corollary to that, you -- I'd like to know how that sort of perhaps dovetails into your own M&A strategy. And specifically, you clearly want to do more deals, you just don't want to put the cart before the horse. But if things were to deteriorate, does that cause you to do more deals sooner, perhaps, or push them out? Or just how are you thinking about that? And I'm sorry, the questions are long. There's just a lot of context to it.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me try to hit all the points, and let me know if I miss anything. I think, overall, our strategy is no different than how we operate the company day-to-day, which is we are -- we have a very -- on a relative basis, a very flexible cost structure. We a
componenttext: Let me try to hit all the points, and let me know if I miss anything. I think, overall, our strategy is no different than how we operate the company day-to-day, which is we are -- we have a very -- on a relative basis, a very flexible cost structure. We are a fast reactor. We're not a predictor of the future. And I think, as you're seeing in Welding right now, we are certainly confident in our ability to react in an effective way to whatever sort of the cards -- however the cards play out in Europe. I think right now, and it's certainly reflected in our Q2 results, we're not seeing anything yet. It's obviously very early. But I think, overall, I don't really see any difference between sort of the kind of contingency planning we would do around the whole Brexit situation and any other contingency planning that we would do relative to global macroeconomic conditions generally in whatever region of the world. The -- from an M&A standpoint, the goal, I would say and I'd go back to what we've talked about repeatedly, which is the primary focus of the company right now, is that we've got a collection, in our view, of terrific assets and our primary focus is operating the assets we already have to the best of our ability. And there's certainly more runway to go in terms of getting to our -- from where we are to what we view as our full potential. And the M&A we're doing is really largely bolting on to one of the existing 7 businesses that we have. And as those opportunities -- if -- should other opportunities emerge that are a good fit, we will certainly not hesitate. But I think we are very convicted about our ability to continue to grow earnings, growing and continue to improve the operating metrics of the businesses that we own.
