headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Welcome, and thank you all for standing by. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at any point. And now, I would like to turn the call over now to your host, Mr. Michael Larsen, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Gary, and good morning, and welcome to ITW's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I am Michael Larsen, ITW's Senior Vice President and CFO, and joining me this morning is our Chairman and CEO, Scott Santi. During today's call, we wi
componenttext:
All right. Thank you, Gary, and good morning, and welcome to ITW's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I am Michael Larsen, ITW's Senior Vice President and CFO, and joining me this morning is our Chairman and CEO, Scott Santi. 
During today's call, we will discuss our third quarter 2016 financial results and update you on our 2016 earnings forecast. Before we get to the results, let me remind you that this presentation contains our financial forecast for the fourth quarter and full year 2016 as well as other forward-looking statements identified on this slide. We refer you to the company's 2015 Form 10-K and Form 10-Q for the second quarter of 2016 for more detail about important risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectation. 
Also, this presentation uses certain non-GAAP measures, and while we use very few non-GAAP measures, a reconciliation of those non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures is contained in the press release. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael, and good morning. In Q3, ITW delivered another quarter of high-quality earnings growth with record operating income, operating margin and return on invested capital performance. In the quarter, we generated 8% GAAP earnings per share grow
componenttext:
Thanks, Michael, and good morning. In Q3, ITW delivered another quarter of high-quality earnings growth with record operating income, operating margin and return on invested capital performance. In the quarter, we generated 8% GAAP earnings per share growth, operating margin of 23.1%, which if you exclude the 80 basis points of the EF&C acquisition dilution, was 23.9% on an apples-to-apples basis, and after tax return on invested capital came in at 23%.  The key driver of our performance continues to be the execution of our strategy. The third quarter marked the 12th quarter in a row that our enterprise strategy initiatives delivered more than 100 basis points of margin expansion. 
In addition, we are continuing to make good progress in executing our pivot to growth with 6 of our 7 segments again delivering positive organic growth in Q3 despite a macro environment that obviously remains challenging. Through the execution of our strategy, we have grown earnings per share by an average of 15% per year over the last 4 years with almost no help from the market environment.  But we still I believe, have to go [ph] before we are operating to our full potential. We look forward to providing an update on the work that we have ahead of us to deliver on ITW's full performance potential at our annual Investor Day in December. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Michael, who will provide you with more detail regarding our Q3 performance and our updated Q4 2016 forecast. Michael?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. ITW's third quarter was another high-quality quarter with solid earnings growth, continued margin expansion and solid free cash flow. EPS was up 8% to $1.50, slightly ahead of the midpoints of our guidance due to solid execution and that
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. ITW's third quarter was another high-quality quarter with solid earnings growth, continued margin expansion and solid free cash flow. EPS was up 8% to $1.50, slightly ahead of the midpoints of our guidance due to solid execution and that result in [ph] better margin performance.  
Total revenue was $3.5 billion, up 4%, and organic growth was 2%, in line with guidance. 
Overall demand was pretty steady-state as we moved through the quarter in what continues to be a fairly challenging environment, particularly on the capital equipment side. Nevertheless, 6 of 7 segments delivered positive organic growth, and key regions such as North America, Europe, Asia Pacific, including China, were all positive.
In my opinion, the highlight this quarter was ITW's record operating margin performance of 23.1%, 23.9% when you exclude EF&C, and all 7 segments performing above 21%. Operating income grew 6% to $808 million and after-tax return on invested capital improved 140 basis points to 23%. Both of these performance metrics were all-time highs for ITW. 
We invested more than $150 million in capital equipments, new project -- products and projects to simplify our businesses. Free cash flow of 101% of net income was a little lower than last year due to some quarterly timing, but year-to-date, we're on track at 94% which compares to 96% at this point last year. We typically have a strong Q4 and we expect to finish the year above 100%.  In addition, we repurchased shares for $500 million and expect to complete this year's program with another $500 million in Q4, bringing the total to $2 billion. 
Finally, as you saw in August, ITW announced a dividend increase of 18%. So overall, a pretty straightforward good quarter as ITW continue to execute well and deliver strong results. 
On Slide 5, starting with the key drivers of our operating margin performance. The strong execution on our Enterprise Initiatives contributed 120 basis points. Price/cost was slightly favorable. Volume leverage of 30 basis points was offset by a number of other items. And EF&C diluted margin 80 basis points, resulting in 23.1%, a record for the company, and like I said, 23.9% if you're comparing to our long-term performance goal of 23%-plus. 
On Page 6, really good operating performance across the 7 segments, with all segments at or above 21% for the first time ever. I wanted to point out that Automotive OEM margins, as expected, were diluted 370 basis points by EF&C, and that the core business is obviously still very strong at 25%-plus. In construction, restructuring related to the simplification of our European manufacturing footprint created a drag of 190 basis points. The other segment numbers speak for themselves, really strong performance again this quarter. 
Turning to the segment discussion and starting with our Automotive OEM. A really good quarter on the top line as organic revenue grew 7% due to strong penetration gains in every region. In North America, 5% organic growth compares favorably to auto builds of 2%, and that includes a 1% decline at the so-called D3 [ph] where we have relatively higher content. 
Europe was up 5% with 700 basis points of penetration gains as overall builds were down 2%. And China was up 40% with very significant penetration gains due to new product launches this quarter. Also, you may recall that China was down 5% in this quarter last year, making for a relatively easy comparison. 
Food Equipment was up 1% organically, with North America equipment up 3% due to a difficult year-over-year comparison. You may recall that in the third quarter last year, equipment was up 8%. International equipment was down 3% and service was up 1%. Based on Q3 exit run rates and backlog and a more normalized comparison, we expect the Q4 organic growth rate to be more in line with recent trends, so continued solid demand in Food Equipment.  Also, continued strong margin performance as 27.4% was the highest margin in the company this quarter. 
A good quarter for Test & Measurement and Electronics as organic revenue grew 7% due primarily to an easy comparison. Last year in the third quarter, this segment was down 11%. 
Electronics was up 13% and Test & Measurement was up 1% in what continues to be a fairly sluggish capital investment demand environment. However, the solid margin expansion is really encouraging and something we've talked about on this call before. Margin improved 440 basis points to 21%, with 190 basis points from Enterprise Initiatives and the balance primarily from volume leverage. 
While the demand environment in welding is stable, it is still pretty challenging, as evidenced by the 9% decline in year-over-year revenues. The decline breaks down as 4 points from oil and gas, 3 points from industrial, which is mostly heavy equipment related to agriculture, infrastructure and mining, and then 2 points from commercial. 
The brighter story is on the margin front as the Welding team continues to do an excellent job managing the cost structure through this cycle while preserving our strong position in the marketplace and being ready to fully participate as things eventually turn around. Despite peak to trough revenues being down about 20%, operating margin is 26.5% this quarter, which is only 150 basis points below peak margins.  In the third quarter, benefits from Enterprise Initiatives and the restructuring projects we talked about last quarter contributed 240 basis points to margin expansion. 
As we've said before, our Welding segment remains a good example of how resilient the ITW business model is across a wide range of economic scenarios. 
Polymers & Fluids delivered another quarter of positive organic revenue growth, up 1%. On a regional basis, international was up 3% and North America was down 1%, mostly due to lower demand on the industrial MRO side of the business. Margin improved 200 basis points to 21%, driven by initiatives and restructuring savings. 
Demand in Construction Products held pretty steady this quarter as this segment grew 2% organically. Construction also had a challenging comparison to last year when North America was up 7%. This quarter, North America was up 1% as compared to down 1% in Q2. And in this quarter, commercial grew 5%, renovation and remodeling was up 4% and residential was down slightly 1 point. [ph] 
Asia Pacific was up 2%. Europe was pretty good, up 2%, but below the Q2 growth rates of 7% and 6%, respectively. And we talked about the margins, 24.5% in Construction if you exclude the European certification project this quarter. 
Finally, Specialty Products, organic revenue essentially flat, with international up 3% and North America down slightly. Our consumer packaging consumable businesses in this segment are growing solidly, offset by weaker demand on the capital equipment side. Good progress on the margin side with an increase of 210 basis points to 26.1%, driven by 180 basis points from Enterprise Initiatives. 
Turning to Page 10, our updated guidance for 2016. 
As you saw this morning, we are raising the midpoint of our full year EPS guidance and narrowing the range to $5.56 to $5.66, which represents 9% earnings growth at the midpoint. As usual, we're assuming current foreign exchange rates, which given the recent strengthening of the dollar against the pound and the euro, creates a few pennies of currency translation headwind in the fourth quarter. 
As a result, the full year guidance increase of $0.01 is essentially the $0.03 peak [ph] from the third quarter, partially offset by $0.02 of additional currency translation headwind in the fourth quarter at today's foreign exchange rates. 
We expect full year 2016 operating margin to be above 22.5%, a new full year record for the company, and up from 21.4% last year. Keep in mind that EF&C dilutes full year margin by approximately 50 basis points. In other words, excluding EF&C, we would be talking about approximately 23% operating margin for the year. 
For the fourth quarter, as usual, our forecast assumes Q3 exit run rates, which equates to organic growth of 0% to 2%. And embedded in that organic growth forecast is a steady-state demand assumption that we feel is pretty reasonable in light of the relatively stable demand trends across our business portfolio in Q3.
We expect operating margin of approximately 21.5%, which is greater than 22% when you exclude EF&C, which compares to 20.7% in Q4 last year. So continued strong margin expansion in Q4. 
Finally, EPS guidance is $1.31 to $1.41, which is 11% earnings growth at the midpoint, marking a pretty strong finish to the year. 
So that concludes our prepared remarks and we'll now open up the call to your questions.

Yes. So John, I would just -- I wouldn't read too much into this quarter in Food Equipment. As you know, the quarterly trends can bounce around a little bit. I think you can look at the year-to-date numbers up in that 3% to 4% range, we expect to end up in the same place in Q4 and for the full year. So in Food Equipment, more broadly, we continue to see strength. And on the institutional side, which is the majority of our business, particularly in refrigeration, and then on the scale side and the retail business. But really, nothing to be too concerned about in terms of the demand environment. Pretty stable as we went through the quarter and will be back on trend in Q4.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] Our exposures there really fall into 2 buckets. One is largely a cleanroom [ph] MRO collection of businesses. That's a pretty business and then the other piece, which is where we saw some of the big driver of the year-on-year growth improvement was
componenttext:
[ph] 
Our exposures there really fall into 2 buckets. One is largely a cleanroom [ph] MRO collection of businesses. That's a pretty business and then the other piece, which is where we saw some of the big driver of the year-on-year growth improvement was really on the equipment side, so we're producing equipment that people use to produce printed circuit boards. And that business again, Michael talked about it, was up somewhat in the quarter but also on a very low comp on the prior year. So I think we would not describe that business as being down significantly or being under pressure, but it's -- I also wouldn't read a lot into the year-on-year growth number either.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: That's fair. And just lastly, your auto strength in China, Michael, you attributed to product launches. Is this a 1-quarter phenomenon? Or are you gearing up to try and penetrate the China auto sector? Like does this have more legs beyond the quarter, I guess, is what I'm wondering?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think this has a lot more legs to it as we go forward and into next year and beyond. Obviously, 40% -- builds were up 20%-plus, but in terms of kind of what the penetration gains can be, I think that's directionally, that's where we'd expect it to
componenttext: Yes, I think this has a lot more legs to it as we go forward and into next year and beyond. Obviously, 40% -- builds were up 20%-plus, but in terms of kind of what the penetration gains can be, I think that's directionally, that's where we'd expect it to be going forward.

componenttext: And for our next question, it's from Joe Ritchie from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice fundamental quarter. Maybe just focusing on auto, I think there seems to be a lot of concern out there right now, giving potentially peaking auto build and Ford's comments about idling capacity. You mentioned in your prepared remarks that the big 3 w
componenttext: Nice fundamental quarter. Maybe just focusing on auto, I think there seems to be a lot of concern out there right now, giving potentially peaking auto build and Ford's comments about idling capacity. You mentioned in your prepared remarks that the big 3 was down 1 [ph] but the outgrowth in North America was still really strong. So maybe just provide a little bit more color on where you're seeing the outgrowth and expectation longer term to continue to outgrow auto production?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've talked about this a number of times in the past. The auto business for us is one where we do have a reasonable amount of forward visibility, typically 2 to 3 years. So we have -- feel very good about our pipeline of new content going on new vehicles
componenttext: We've talked about this a number of times in the past. The auto business for us is one where we do have a reasonable amount of forward visibility, typically 2 to 3 years. So we have -- feel very good about our pipeline of new content going on new vehicles. Certainly, we will be impacted on a relative basis based on the overall build levels in the market, but our ability to continue to outgrow whatever the market growth rate is if it flattens out, we would still expect to be positive by 200 to 400 basis points. And that's pretty much a 3-year kind of look when we've got some great backlogs, some great programs in place and a lot of really compelling things we're working on. So it's an area that we are very bullish on a long-term basis.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, Joe, specifically to the D3 but being down 1 [ph] the expectation for them is to be down again in Q4, and that's fully embedded in our forecast. And I think similar to in food, you'll see a growth rate in line with what we've done hi
componenttext: And I would just add, Joe, specifically to the D3 but being down 1 [ph] the expectation for them is to be down again in Q4, and that's fully embedded in our forecast. And I think similar to in food, you'll see a growth rate in line with what we've done historically on the auto side here in Q4.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. No, that's helpful. And maybe touching base on the margins on auto. I know you guys are under consistent pricing pressure but at the same time can really get a lot of production efficiency to help continue to grow margins in that segment. Given th
componenttext: Got it. No, that's helpful. And maybe touching base on the margins on auto. I know you guys are under consistent pricing pressure but at the same time can really get a lot of production efficiency to help continue to grow margins in that segment. Given that it's longer cycle and maybe have a little bit more visibility on auto, I'm just curious, kind of compare and contrast auto versus Welding because you've done such a great job in continuing to expand margins in your Welding segment despite of rollover in growth. I'm just curious how resilient you think your auto margins can be if we do start to see a slowdown in auto?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the auto margins largely about the value add content we put in the product, so we have talked, I think, a number of occasions of our business being very niche, very oriented around solving tough problems for our OEM customers. We are not playing in
componenttext: Well, the auto margins largely about the value add content we put in the product, so we have talked, I think, a number of occasions of our business being very niche, very oriented around solving tough problems for our OEM customers. We are not playing in the bumpers on whatever model of car you're talking about. We're not an RFQ bidder. We are a problem solver, so from the standpoint of the overall margin performance on our business, largely as a function of our discipline around the types of opportunities we're willing to engage it with our customers on and how well our skill set matches up with what they need a partner to do. So I think we're in really good shape. These are typically longer term 6-, 7-year kinds of programs. And certainly, there are some commitments often embedded in our annual cost [indiscernible] those are fully baked in terms of our knowledge upfront. And we will work with your delivering value not only on the design of the actual solution but on an ongoing basis continue to drive benefits for customers that also drive benefits to the company.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for our next question, it's from Scott Davis from Barclays.
componenttext: And for our next question, it's from Scott Davis from Barclays.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Trying to get a sense of when Welding does come back, what type of margin structure we can expect. And the question really here is that how much discretionary spend has been cut in things that you're going to add back pretty quickly or invest or spend or
componenttext: Trying to get a sense of when Welding does come back, what type of margin structure we can expect. And the question really here is that how much discretionary spend has been cut in things that you're going to add back pretty quickly or invest or spend or how you define it, I guess, but just general spend that may have to come back that would indicate that may be margins don't go up when Welding comes back but more flattish. Just some color on that would be helpful.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Your final comment would be very hard for me to see any sooner whether that will be the case. It seems Welding has done a really nice job of adjusting cost structure to the overall current demand environment but there's nothing. We've also been very
componenttext: Yes. Your final comment would be very hard for me to see any sooner whether that will be the case. It seems Welding has done a really nice job of adjusting cost structure to the overall current demand environment but there's nothing. We've also been very clear and they've worked very hard and making sure that all of our sort of important growth investments remain fully funded to allow those down cycles. So it is largely a matter of a lot of re-application of 80/20, a lot of focus and prioritization. It's not about cutting muscle, it's just about adjusting the cost structure. So from the standpoint of how it looks on a go-forward basis, I would have a hard time seeing any scenario where the incremental margins on the recovery would be far outside of our traditional 30% to 35% bucket.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just as a follow-on, if you think in terms of some normalization in Welding sequentially, I mean, when do you think you'd be -- I know this is hard but given that oil prices are back up over $50 and emerging markets are getting a
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just as a follow-on, if you think in terms of some normalization in Welding sequentially, I mean, when do you think you'd be -- I know this is hard but given that oil prices are back up over $50 and emerging markets are getting a bit better and such, I mean, do you get a sense of a book-to-bill in the 1, 1.0 or a little bit better range at -- in earlier in '17 or you still think it might be more of a mid to later?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd tell you what, I would probably not want to get into the forecasting business here. It's been -- we're going up on 8 quarters now of some pretty significant contraction. We've got to see it flatten out first, I would say, from a standpoint of just seq
componenttext: I'd tell you what, I would probably not want to get into the forecasting business here. It's been -- we're going up on 8 quarters now of some pretty significant contraction. We've got to see it flatten out first, I would say, from a standpoint of just sequential daily order rate demand trends, it's been pretty solid, pretty steady state for the last 3 or 4 quarters here. But it's not -- we're certainly not seeing any signs of any pickup at this point. I would really hesitate to call a turn at some point in the future, but we're well positioned to participate when it happens. And I think we're managing the business through this down cycle pretty well.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Not? Okay, that's interesting. When I think about the incremental margins you just put off and kind of simplistically, I think of is when you provide that organic margin change. componenttext: Well, I think, David, consistent with what we've said before and I think Scott just mentioned this and when we're talking about Welding is we would expect our incremental margins to continue to be in that 30% to 35% range.

componenttext: [indiscernible] Those are the buckets, right? I mean, whatever you can do organically and obviously, the pressure's on a little bit as we pivot away from the Enterprise Initiatives. I assume we'll get some clarity on how to think about the next few years. And I know it's hard to forecast. Just to pivot here again from a margin story internally to organic was always the benefit of your strong cash flow and capital allocation. It is sort of an interesting moment for the stock's evolution, right? I mean, look at more than just, "Hey, here's the '17 outlook." Is that fair?

componenttext: Scott, so when expecting margin in Test & Measurement to improve as your Enterprise Initiatives continue to ramp up. Were you surprised by the speed of the margin ramp-up? headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes, the second answer is -- the answer to the second question is no. Great fundamentals in that business. And I would say, as with all of our 7 businesses, they are, in terms of the work they've done moving through these enterprise strategy initiatives, they all started in a different place. They all had their own level of work to be done and in Test & Measurement's case, there are recent progress in terms of outcome. It's noteworthy but they've been doing things inside that haven't necessarily showed up in terms of margin for the last 6 or 8 quarters. And so I'm very pleased with now what's starting to show up but they've been on a pretty good track all the way long in terms of what they've been working on to get where they can be and as you said, still have more room to go.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's great. And then just shifting to construction, can you talk about what happened this quarter? You said BSS reduced margins by 190 basis points. But I would've thought that much of the simplification in that segment had already occurred. I know you've been trying to simplify your European construction footprint for some time. But BSS seems a little more out of the blue, I guess, than I would've thought?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it wasn't necessarily out of the blue but there was -- from day 1, there's a lot to get done there. They've gone through a couple of cycles and this particular project that has certainly a visible impact on margin in Q3 was one that has been in the
componenttext: Well, it wasn't necessarily out of the blue but there was -- from day 1, there's a lot to get done there. They've gone through a couple of cycles and this particular project that has certainly a visible impact on margin in Q3 was one that has been in the planning cycle for a while. But it was among our most complex structures in the company if you go back to 20 [ph] -- I'm talking about European construction. And so we've talked in the past about not only the work we've been doing but the way we've been doing the work in terms of doing it in a methodical fashion and the way it doesn't impair our ability to serve our customers and generate some reasonable incremental progress along the way. So while this was -- this particular activity was known, we knew we were going to have to do with almost back to the beginning. It's one where we also are now at a place from a standpoint of timing where we're in a position to do it and do it in a way that doesn't impact our ability to serve our customers in the region. So it wasn't out of the blue from our standpoint by any stretch.

So in construction, this is -- the expense are front-end loaded based on the economy rules but the benefits ultimately start to show up, maybe not fully in Q4 but certainly over the next 3 quarters or so.

componenttext: Yes, I'm not sure how you got that, Nigel. Q4 is going to look a lot like Q3 in terms of the EF&C impact. So you saw the margin dilution, 80 basis points at the enterprise level. componenttext: I wouldn't say it's a slowdown. Again, if you go back and look, service in North America was up 4% in Q3 last year, we're up 2% this year. That's pretty solid. componenttext: No, that's not it at all. I think if you go back, I don't think we've put up 4% to 5% in service since 2014. But I think going forward, that's an expectation. componenttext: I think what I would prefer to do is wait through the results of this planning cycle that we just talked about. We will give you a good update on the end of December. But I think before we do any speculating, we'll let our businesses run their plans for '17 through and then we'll have a better picture there. It's clearly, at some point, it will start winding down. I would also argue on the other side that we are -- this is activity that is very healthy from a standpoint of profitability and focus. So to the extent that there's continued activity there that worked out, you're going to continue to sported until we get all the stuff out here that needs to go so we can really focus on highly profitable parts of our business that we think at a long-term growth potential. So we're not -- so we'll see what happens. I would expect a that certainly things start to at least stabilized there, if not, start to slow down but until we go through the actual details of what our businesses have in mind for next year, it's hard to comment.

componenttext: Okay. And then within your 35-or-so percent incremental margin targets, how should we think about how much of that is driven by pricing versus volume? headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pricing is not a big margin driver for us here. Really, the big margin driver is and has been, I think Scott mentioned 12 quarters in a row, of the Enterprise Initiatives. That's really what's driving the margin expansion. And the incremental margins if y
componenttext: Pricing is not a big margin driver for us here. Really, the big margin driver is and has been, I think Scott mentioned 12 quarters in a row, of the Enterprise Initiatives. That's really what's driving the margin expansion. And the incremental margins if you go back and look historically, that's where the company's been for a very long time and that 30% to 35% range. And really on the pricing side, all we're trying to do is to offset some material cost inflation but it's not the key driver of our growth or of our margin expansion.

componenttext: No, there's really nothing interesting to report. componenttextpreview: We're not seeing any material cost inflation at this point. And when we do, we will react, like I said, and do our best in the to offset that with efficiency and with price.
componenttext: We're not seeing any material cost inflation at this point. And when we do, we will react, like I said, and do our best in the to offset that with efficiency and with price.

componenttext: I just I guess just 2 follow-up questions. One, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned free cash flow, the free cash flow was a little light and it sounded like there was some timing issues. Can you just talk around that, sort of what the issues were and how much incremental that is to the fourth quarter? And then second, I guess when I look at your construction revenues on an organic basis, it's still up but obviously, the increases are declining. So just a little color on your concern whether that market is turning at all particular with the AVI data points that we're getting at because commercial is also very strong within the Construction segment.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The free cash flow, like I said, on a year-to-date basis were exactly what we were last year. So there's things can move around a little bit on a quarterly basis. For example, our CapEx number is up a little bit this quarter but year-to-date, it's exactly
componenttext: The free cash flow, like I said, on a year-to-date basis were exactly what we were last year. So there's things can move around a little bit on a quarterly basis. For example, our CapEx number is up a little bit this quarter but year-to-date, it's exactly in line with last year. And then maybe some larger payments that go out 1 quarter versus another. We fully expect we'll be at above 100% for the year, which would imply a strong Q4, which seasonally that's what we usually do. So other than that, feel very good about the free cash flow performance again on the construction side, I just add what we said earlier. Demand is pretty steady state. There's some comp issues that we're dealing with, but we feel good about using current run rates to model the fourth quarter and we're not expecting any big changes from where we are right now.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Gary, and good morning, and welcome to ITW's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I am Michael Larsen, ITW's Senior Vice President and CFO, and joining me this morning is our Chairman and CEO, Scott Santi. During today's call, we wi
componenttext:
All right. Thank you, Gary, and good morning, and welcome to ITW's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. I am Michael Larsen, ITW's Senior Vice President and CFO, and joining me this morning is our Chairman and CEO, Scott Santi. 
During today's call, we will discuss our third quarter 2016 financial results and update you on our 2016 earnings forecast. Before we get to the results, let me remind you that this presentation contains our financial forecast for the fourth quarter and full year 2016 as well as other forward-looking statements identified on this slide. We refer you to the company's 2015 Form 10-K and Form 10-Q for the second quarter of 2016 for more detail about important risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectation. 
Also, this presentation uses certain non-GAAP measures, and while we use very few non-GAAP measures, a reconciliation of those non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures is contained in the press release. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael, and good morning. In Q3, ITW delivered another quarter of high-quality earnings growth with record operating income, operating margin and return on invested capital performance. In the quarter, we generated 8% GAAP earnings per share grow
componenttext:
Thanks, Michael, and good morning. In Q3, ITW delivered another quarter of high-quality earnings growth with record operating income, operating margin and return on invested capital performance. In the quarter, we generated 8% GAAP earnings per share growth, operating margin of 23.1%, which if you exclude the 80 basis points of the EF&C acquisition dilution, was 23.9% on an apples-to-apples basis, and after tax return on invested capital came in at 23%.  The key driver of our performance continues to be the execution of our strategy. The third quarter marked the 12th quarter in a row that our enterprise strategy initiatives delivered more than 100 basis points of margin expansion. 
In addition, we are continuing to make good progress in executing our pivot to growth with 6 of our 7 segments again delivering positive organic growth in Q3 despite a macro environment that obviously remains challenging. Through the execution of our strategy, we have grown earnings per share by an average of 15% per year over the last 4 years with almost no help from the market environment.  But we still have a ways to go before we are operating to our full potential. We look forward to providing an update on the work that we have ahead of us to deliver on ITW's full performance potential at our annual Investor Day in December. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Michael, who will provide you with more detail regarding our Q3 performance and our updated Q4 2016 forecast. Michael?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. ITW's third quarter was another high-quality quarter with solid earnings growth, continued margin expansion and solid free cash flow. EPS was up 8% to $1.50, slightly ahead of the midpoints of our guidance due to solid execution and the
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. ITW's third quarter was another high-quality quarter with solid earnings growth, continued margin expansion and solid free cash flow. EPS was up 8% to $1.50, slightly ahead of the midpoints of our guidance due to solid execution and the resulting better margin performance.  
Total revenue was $3.5 billion, up 4%, and organic growth was 2%, in line with guidance. 
Overall demand was pretty steady-state as we moved through the quarter in what continues to be a fairly challenging environment, particularly on the capital equipment side. Nevertheless, 6 of 7 segments delivered positive organic growth, and key regions such as North America, Europe, Asia Pacific, including China, were all positive.
In my opinion, the highlight this quarter was ITW's record operating margin performance of 23.1%, 23.9% when you exclude EF&C, and all 7 segments performing above 21%. Operating income grew 6% to $808 million and after-tax return on invested capital improved 140 basis points to 23%. Both of these performance metrics were all-time highs for ITW. 
We invested more than $150 million in capital equipments, new project -- products and projects to simplify our businesses. Free cash flow of 101% of net income was a little lower than last year due to some quarterly timing, but year-to-date, we're on track at 94% which compares to 96% at this point last year. We typically have a strong Q4 and we expect to finish the year above 100%.  In addition, we repurchased shares for $500 million and expect to complete this year's program with another $500 million in Q4, bringing the total to $2 billion. 
Finally, as you saw in August, ITW announced a dividend increase of 18%. So overall, a pretty straightforward good quarter as ITW continue to execute well and deliver strong results. 
On Slide 5, starting with the key drivers of our operating margin performance. The strong execution on our Enterprise Initiatives contributed 120 basis points. Price/cost was slightly favorable. Volume leverage of 30 basis points was offset by a number of other items. And EF&C diluted margin 80 basis points, resulting in 23.1%, a record for the company, and like I said, 23.9% if you're comparing to our long-term performance goal of 23%-plus. 
On Page 6, really good operating performance across the 7 segments, with all segments at or above 21% for the first time ever. I wanted to point out that Automotive OEM margins, as expected, were diluted 370 basis points by EF&C, and that the core business is obviously still very strong at 25%-plus. In construction, restructuring related to the simplification of our European manufacturing footprint created a drag of 190 basis points. The other segment numbers speak for themselves, really strong performance again this quarter. 
Turning to the segment discussion and starting with our Automotive OEM. A really good quarter on the top line as organic revenue grew 7% due to strong penetration gains in every region. In North America, 5% organic growth compares favorably to auto builds of 2%, and that includes a 1% decline at the so-called D3 ph] where we have relatively higher content. 
Europe was up 5% with 700 basis points of penetration gains as overall builds were down 2%. And China was up 40% with very significant penetration gains due to new product launches this quarter. Also, you may recall that China was down 5% in this quarter last year, making for a relatively easy comparison. 
Food Equipment was up 1% organically, with North America equipment up 3% due to a difficult year-over-year comparison. You may recall that in the third quarter last year, equipment was up 8%. International equipment was down 3% and service was up 1%. Based on Q3 exit run rates and backlog and a more normalized comparison, we expect the Q4 organic growth rate to be more in line with recent trends, so continued solid demand in Food Equipment.  Also, continued strong margin performance as 27.4% was the highest margin in the company this quarter. 
A good quarter for Test & Measurement and Electronics as organic revenue grew 7% due primarily to an easy comparison. Last year in the third quarter, this segment was down 11%. 
Electronics was up 13% and Test & Measurement was up 1% in what continues to be a fairly sluggish capital investment demand environment. However, the solid margin expansion is really encouraging and something we've talked about on this call before. Margin improved 440 basis points to 21%, with 190 basis points from Enterprise Initiatives and the balance primarily from volume leverage. 
While the demand environment in welding is stable, it is still pretty challenging, as evidenced by the 9% decline in year-over-year revenues. The decline breaks down as 4 points from oil and gas, 3 points from industrial, which is mostly heavy equipment related to agriculture, infrastructure and mining, and then 2 points from commercial. 
The brighter story is on the margin front as the Welding team continues to do an excellent job managing the cost structure through this cycle while preserving our strong position in the marketplace and being ready to fully participate as things eventually turn around. Despite peak to trough revenues being down about 20%, operating margin is 26.5% this quarter, which is only 150 basis points below peak margins.  In the third quarter, benefits from Enterprise Initiatives and the restructuring projects we talked about last quarter contributed 240 basis points to margin expansion. 
As we've said before, our Welding segment remains a good example of how resilient the ITW business model is across a wide range of economic scenarios. 
Polymers & Fluids delivered another quarter of positive organic revenue growth, up 1%. On a regional basis, international was up 3% and North America was down 1%, mostly due to lower demand on the industrial MRO side of the business. Margin improved 200 basis points to 21%, driven by initiatives and restructuring savings. 
Demand in Construction Products held pretty steady this quarter as this segment grew 2% organically. Construction also had a challenging comparison to last year when North America was up 7%. This quarter, North America was up 1% as compared to down 1% in Q2. And in this quarter, commercial grew 5%, renovation and remodeling was up 4% and residential was down slightly 1 point. 
Asia Pacific was up 2%. Europe was pretty good, up 2%, but below the Q2 growth rates of 7% and 6%, respectively. And we talked about the margins, 24.5% in Construction if you exclude the European certification project this quarter. 
Finally, Specialty Products, organic revenue essentially flat, with international up 3% and North America down slightly. Our consumer packaging consumable businesses in this segment are growing solidly, offset by weaker demand on the capital equipment side. Good progress on the margin side with an increase of 210 basis points to 26.1%, driven by 180 basis points from Enterprise Initiatives. 
Turning to Page 10, our updated guidance for 2016. 
As you saw this morning, we are raising the midpoint of our full year EPS guidance and narrowing the range to $5.56 to $5.66, which represents 9% earnings growth at the midpoint. As usual, we're assuming current foreign exchange rates, which given the recent strengthening of the dollar against the pound and the euro, creates a few pennies of currency translation headwind in the fourth quarter. 
As a result, the full year guidance increase of $0.01 is essentially the $0.03 peak from the third quarter, partially offset by $0.02 of additional currency translation headwind in the fourth quarter at today's foreign exchange rates. 
We expect full year 2016 operating margin to be above 22.5%, a new full year record for the company, and up from 21.4% last year. Keep in mind that EF&C dilutes full year margin by approximately 50 basis points. In other words, excluding EF&C, we would be talking about approximately 23% operating margin for the year. 
For the fourth quarter, as usual, our forecast assumes Q3 exit run rates, which equates to organic growth of 0% to 2%. And embedded in that organic growth forecast is a steady-state demand assumption that we feel is pretty reasonable in light of the relatively stable demand trends across our business portfolio in Q3.
We expect operating margin of approximately 21.5%, which is greater than 22% when you exclude EF&C, which compares to 20.7% in Q4 last year. So continued strong margin expansion in Q4. 
Finally, EPS guidance is $1.31 to $1.41, which is 11% earnings growth at the midpoint, marking a pretty strong finish to the year. 
So that concludes our prepared remarks and we'll now open up the call to your questions.

Maybe to just sort of put the international softness and the restaurant issue sort of into a context for us?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So John, I would just -- I wouldn't read too much into this quarter in Food Equipment. As you know, the quarterly trends can bounce around a little bit. I think you can look at the year-to-date numbers up in that 3% to 4% range, we expect to end up i
componenttext: Yes. So John, I would just -- I wouldn't read too much into this quarter in Food Equipment. As you know, the quarterly trends can bounce around a little bit. I think you can look at the year-to-date numbers up in that 3% to 4% range, we expect to end up in the same place in Q4 and for the full year. So in Food Equipment, more broadly, we continue to see strength. And on the institutional side, which is the majority of our business, particularly in refrigeration, and then on the scale side and the retail business. But really, nothing to be too concerned about in terms of the demand environment. Pretty stable as we went through the quarter and will be back on trend in Q4.

componenttext: Okay. And then Test & Measurement and Electronics. I think some people don't fully appreciate what's in the Electronics segment. And I make the commentary in the context that 3M and others have experienced consumer electronics weakness. In their situation, it's OLED conversion and smartphone saturation. And I guess I'm wondering, are you experiencing any kind of consumer softness within the confines of the umbrella of this electronics up 13% organically?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our exposures there really fall into 2 buckets. One is largely a cleanroom MRO collection of businesses. That's a pretty steady eddie business. And then the other piece, which is where we saw some of the -- the big driver of the year-on-year growth improv
componenttext: Our exposures there really fall into 2 buckets. One is largely a cleanroom MRO collection of businesses. That's a pretty steady eddie business. And then the other piece, which is where we saw some of the -- the big driver of the year-on-year growth improvement was really on the equipment side, so we're producing equipment that people use to produce printed circuit boards. And that business again, Michael talked about it, was up somewhat in the quarter but also on a very low comp on the prior year. So I think we would not describe that business as being down significantly or being under pressure, but it's -- I also wouldn't read a lot into the year-on-year growth number either.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair. And just lastly, your auto strength in China, Michael, you attributed it to product launches. Is this a one-quarter phenomenon? Or are you gearing up to try and penetrate the China auto sector? Like does this have more legs beyond the quarter
componenttext: That's fair. And just lastly, your auto strength in China, Michael, you attributed it to product launches. Is this a one-quarter phenomenon? Or are you gearing up to try and penetrate the China auto sector? Like does this have more legs beyond the quarter, I guess, is what I'm wondering?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think this has a lot more legs to it as we go forward and into next year and beyond. Obviously, 40% -- builds were up 20%-plus, but in terms of kind of what the penetration gains can be, I think that's directionally -- that's where we'd expect it t
componenttext: Yes, I think this has a lot more legs to it as we go forward and into next year and beyond. Obviously, 40% -- builds were up 20%-plus, but in terms of kind of what the penetration gains can be, I think that's directionally -- that's where we'd expect it to be going forward.

componenttext: Kind of that 2x number, is that what you're saying?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for our next question, it's from Joe Ritchie from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And for our next question, it's from Joe Ritchie from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice fundamental quarter. Maybe just focusing on auto, I think there seems to be a lot of concern out there right now given potentially peaking auto builds and Ford's comments about idling capacity. You mentioned in your prepared remarks that the big 3 wa
componenttext: Nice fundamental quarter. Maybe just focusing on auto, I think there seems to be a lot of concern out there right now given potentially peaking auto builds and Ford's comments about idling capacity. You mentioned in your prepared remarks that the big 3 was down 1, but the outgrowth in North America was still really strong. And so maybe just provide a little bit more color on where you're seeing the outgrowth and expectation longer-term to continue to outgrow auto production?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've talked about this a number of times in the past. But the auto business, for us, is one where we do have a reasonable amount of forward visibility, typically, 2 to 3 years. So we have -- feel very good about our pipeline of new content going on new v
componenttext: We've talked about this a number of times in the past. But the auto business, for us, is one where we do have a reasonable amount of forward visibility, typically, 2 to 3 years. So we have -- feel very good about our pipeline of new content going on new vehicles. Certainly, we will be impacted on a relative basis based on the overall build levels in the market. But our ability to continue to outgrow whatever the market growth rate is, if it flattens out, we would still expect to be positive by 200 to 400 basis points. And that's pretty much a 3-year kind of look when we've got some great backlogs, some great programs in place and a lot of really compelling things we're working on. So it's an area that we are very bullish on, on a long-term basis.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, Joe, specifically to the D3 [ph] being down 1, the expectation for them is to be down again in Q4, and that's fully embedded in our forecast. And I think similar to in food, you'll see a growth rate in line with what we've done histo
componenttext: And I would just add, Joe, specifically to the D3 [ph] being down 1, the expectation for them is to be down again in Q4, and that's fully embedded in our forecast. And I think similar to in food, you'll see a growth rate in line with what we've done historically on the auto side here in Q4.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. No, that's helpful. Maybe touching base on the margins on auto. I know you guys are under consistent pricing pressure, but at the same time, can really get a lot of production efficiency to help continue to grow margins in that segment. Given that
componenttext: Got it. No, that's helpful. Maybe touching base on the margins on auto. I know you guys are under consistent pricing pressure, but at the same time, can really get a lot of production efficiency to help continue to grow margins in that segment. Given that it's longer cycle and maybe have a little bit more visibility on auto, I'm just curious, kind of compare and contrast auto versus Welding, because you've done such a great job at continuing to expand margins in your Welding segment despite a rollover in growth. I'm just curious how resilient you think your auto margins can be if we do start to see a slowdown in auto?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the Auto margin story is largely about the value add content we put in the product, so we have talked, I think, a number of occasions, of our business being very niche-y, very linked at around solving tough problems for our OEM customers. We are not
componenttext: Well, the Auto margin story is largely about the value add content we put in the product, so we have talked, I think, a number of occasions, of our business being very niche-y, very linked at around solving tough problems for our OEM customers. We are not playing in the bumpers on whatever model of car you're talking about. We're not an RFQ bidder. We are a problem solver. So from the standpoint of the overall margin performance in that business, it largely is a function of our discipline around the types of opportunities we're willing to engage it with our customers on and how well our skill set matches up with what they need a partner to do. So I think we're in really good shape. These are typically longer term 6-, 7-year kinds of programs. And certainly, there are some commitments often embedded in terms of annual cost pick up, and those are fully baked in terms of our knowledge upfront. And we will work really hard on delivering value, not only in the design of the actual solution, but on an ongoing basis, continue to drive benefits for customers that also drive benefits to the company.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for our next question, it's from Scott Davis from Barclays.
componenttext: And for our next question, it's from Scott Davis from Barclays.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Trying to get a sense of when Welding does come back, what type of margin structure we can expect. And the question really here is that how much discretionary spend has been cut in things that you're going to have to add back pretty quickly or invest and
componenttext: Trying to get a sense of when Welding does come back, what type of margin structure we can expect. And the question really here is that how much discretionary spend has been cut in things that you're going to have to add back pretty quickly or invest and spend or how you define it, I guess. But just general spend that may have to come back that would indicate that maybe even margins don't go up when Welding comes back, but more flattish. Just some color on that would be helpful.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Your final comment would be very hard for me to see any sooner when that would be the case. We've -- it seems in Welding, we've done a really nice job of adjusting cost structure to the overall current demand environment but there's nothing. We've al
componenttext: Yes. Your final comment would be very hard for me to see any sooner when that would be the case. We've -- it seems in Welding, we've done a really nice job of adjusting cost structure to the overall current demand environment but there's nothing. We've also been very clear, and they've worked very hard in making sure that all of our sort of important growth investments remain fully funded to allow this down cycle. So it is largely a matter of a lot of re-application of 80/20, a lot of focus and prioritization. It's not about cutting muscle, it's just about adjusting the cost structure. So from the standpoint of how it looks on a go-forward basis, I would have a hard time seeing any scenario where the incremental margins on the recovery would be far outside of our traditional 30% to 35% bucket.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just as a follow-on, if you think in terms of some normalization in Welding sequentially, I mean, when do you think you'd be -- I know this is hard, but given that oil prices are back up over $50 and emerging markets are get
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just as a follow-on, if you think in terms of some normalization in Welding sequentially, I mean, when do you think you'd be -- I know this is hard, but given that oil prices are back up over $50 and emerging markets are getting a bit better and such, I mean, do you get a sense of a book-to-bill in the 1, 1.0 or a little bit better range at -- earlier in '17? Or you still think it might be more of a mid to later?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I tell you what, I would probably not want to get into the forecasting business here. It's been -- we're going up on 8 quarters now with some pretty significant contraction. We got to see it flatten out first. I would say, from a standpoint of just sequen
componenttext: I tell you what, I would probably not want to get into the forecasting business here. It's been -- we're going up on 8 quarters now with some pretty significant contraction. We got to see it flatten out first. I would say, from a standpoint of just sequential daily order rate demand trends, it's been pretty solid, pretty steady state for the last 3 or 4 quarters here. But it's not -- we're certainly not seeing any signs of any pickup at this point. I would really hesitate to call a turn at some point in the future, but we're well-positioned to participate in it when it happens, and I think we're managing the business through this down cycle pretty well.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for our next question, it's from David Raso from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And for our next question, it's from David Raso from Evercore ISI.

componenttext: Just first a broad question. Can you set the framework for the December meeting, what we should be expecting, organic growth, Enterprise Initiatives for next year?

componenttext: No. We haven't even been through our full planning cycle yet for '17. So that happens in November, which is always our normal routine, and then we come to December well armed with a pretty good view of what we think we ought to be able to accomplish in the upcoming year.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: I mean, is it fair to say, given next year is officially the last year of the Enterprise Initiatives, that yes, there's a year left of that, but the meeting's going to pivot more trying to focus on can you accelerate organic growth with internal initiatives? I mean, is that the...

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily.
componenttext: Not necessarily.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not? Okay, that's interesting. When I think about the incremental margins you just put up and kind of simplistically, I think of it is when you provide that organic margin change, the straight operating leverage that you provide right before any changes i
componenttext: Not? Okay, that's interesting. When I think about the incremental margins you just put up and kind of simplistically, I think of it is when you provide that organic margin change, the straight operating leverage that you provide right before any changes in variable margin overhead cost, the incremental margins were about 36%, and then obviously went higher when you added some of the Enterprise Initiatives. Whatever you do provide an organic sales growth for '17 at that meeting, how should we be thinking about how you view your organic incremental margins? Right. Because we're trying to pivot away from an internal, hey, we can keep growing these margins 100 bps a year, but at some point, it just gets more challenging. What can you give as an organic and what kind of leverage do you expect just to provide some framework?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Well, I think, David, consistent with what we've said before, and I think Scott just mentioned this and when we're talking about Welding, is we would expect our incremental margins to continue to be in that 30% to 35% range.

componenttext: Those are the buckets, right? Just to pivot here from a margin story internally to organic was always the benefit of your strong cash flow and capital allocation. It is sort of an interesting moment for the stock's evolution, right? I mean, we'll get more than just, "Hey, here's the '17 outlook." Is that fair?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Scott, so we've expected margin in Test & Measurement to improve as your Enterprise Initiatives continue to ramp up. Were you surprised by the speed of the margin ramp-up? Is this -- is it really just new leadership this year taking a fresh look at the business and making more immediate changes than anything else? And is there anything stopping Test & Measurement from being a mid-20% margin business like your other businesses over time?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the second answer is -- the answer to the second question is no. Great fundamentals in that business. And I would say, as with all of our 7 businesses, they are, in terms of the work they've done moving through these enterprise strategy initiatives,
componenttext: Yes, the second answer is -- the answer to the second question is no. Great fundamentals in that business. And I would say, as with all of our 7 businesses, they are, in terms of the work they've done moving through these enterprise strategy initiatives, they all started in a different place. They all had their own level of work to be done, and in Test & Measurement's case, there are recent progress in terms of outcome is noteworthy, but they've been doing things inside that haven't necessarily showed up in terms of margin for the last 6 or 8 quarters. And so I'm very pleased with, now, what's starting to show up, but they've been on a pretty good track all the way along in terms of what they've been working on to get where they can be, and as you said, still have more room to go.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's good, Scott. And then just shifting to construction, can you talk about what happened this quarter? You said BSS reduced margins by 190 basis points. But I would've thought that much of the simplification in that segment had already occurred.
componenttext: Okay, that's good, Scott. And then just shifting to construction, can you talk about what happened this quarter? You said BSS reduced margins by 190 basis points. But I would've thought that much of the simplification in that segment had already occurred. We know you've been trying to simplify your European construction footprint for some time, but the level of BSS seems a little more out of the blue, I guess, than I would've thought.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it wasn't necessarily out of the blue, but there was -- from day 1, we knew that there was a lot to get done there. They've gone through a couple of cycles, and this particular project that has certainly a visible impact on margin in Q3 was one that
componenttext: Well, it wasn't necessarily out of the blue, but there was -- from day 1, we knew that there was a lot to get done there. They've gone through a couple of cycles, and this particular project that has certainly a visible impact on margin in Q3 was one that has been in the planning cycle for a while. But it was among our most complex structures in the company, if you go back to 20 [ph] -- I'm talking about European construction. And so we've talked in the past about not only the work we've been doing, but the way we've been doing the work in terms of doing it in a methodical fashion in a way that doesn't impair our ability to serve our customers and generate some reasonable incremental progress along the way. So while this was -- this particular activity was known, we knew we were going to have to do it almost back to the beginning, it's one where we also are now at a place from the standpoint of timing where we're in a position to do it and do it in a way that doesn't impact our ability to serve our customers in the region. So it wasn't out of the blue from our standpoint by any stretch.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes, yes. Look at Welding from last quarter. I mean, our restructuring, when it is -- when it tends to be that concentrated in the segment, we're doing it every quarter. We talked to you about the overall spend. It's typically spread pretty evenly. We didn't talk about it. It's just part of how we operate it. But in the case of Welding in Q2, we talked about some fairly sizable actions, and then look at the recovery in Q3 already in terms of margin from that. So in Construction, this is -- the expense out of these are front-end loaded based on the accounting rules, but the benefits ultimately start to show up, maybe not fully in Q4, but certainly over the next 3 quarters or so.

componenttext: Yes, I'm not sure how you got that, Nigel. Q4 is going to look a lot like Q3 in terms of the EF&C impact. So you saw the margin dilution, 80 basis points at the enterprise level. We'd expect the same here in Q4. Revenues in Q3 of $117 million, which is in line with what we expected, and we expect something very similar to that here in the fourth quarter. And then finally, on the EPS side, consistent with what we said before, EPS neutral in the first 6 months here in the second half of '16, and then accretive, I would expect it to be accretive as we get into '17 and we have to go through the planning process, as Scott said, and then we'll give you an update when we get to giving guidance for 2017.

componenttext: I wouldn't say maybe it's necessarily a slowdown. I think again, if you go back and look, service in North America was up 4% in Q3 last year, we're up 2% this year. That's pretty solid. But we've also talked about the fact that we think there is more potential here for organic growth, that's probably closer to what we're seeing at least on the equipment side.

componenttext: I know. But I'm asking really about service, and it is a slowdown from the 4% to 5% that you've consistently put up since early 2014. componenttext: No, that's not it at all. I think if you go back and look, I don't think we've put up 4% to 5% in service since 2014. But I think that going forward, that's not an unrealistic expectation. And services is stable here. We had -- we talked about this last quarter, also a little bit of PLS in some parts of the business. But overall, kind of in this low single digit is a pretty good way to think about the business on a go-forward basis from a growth standpoint. And then obviously, as you know, this is a very profitable part of the business, more profitable than the equipment side.

componenttext: Yes, the impact is really on the translation side. So we are -- we have run profitable businesses in the U.K. And when we bring those, we translate those pound -- British pound earnings into U.S. dollars, there's a headwind, and so that's really what we're talking about.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: I think you made indirect reference to this David Raso, but how is your visibility changing on winding down PLS activities? To what extent are you increasingly confident that 2016 is the last main year we'll see it as a headwind?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what I would prefer to do is wait until we go through this planning cycle that we just talked about. We will give you a good update on the end of December. But I think before we do any speculating, we'll let our businesses run their plans fo
componenttext: Well, I think what I would prefer to do is wait until we go through this planning cycle that we just talked about. We will give you a good update on the end of December. But I think before we do any speculating, we'll let our businesses run their plans for '17 through and then we'll have a better picture there. It's -- clearly, at some point, it will start winding down. I would also argue on the other side that we're -- we have -- we are -- this is an activity that is very healthy from the standpoint of profitability and focus. So to the extent that there's continued activity there that work now, we're going to continue to support it until we get all the stuff out of here that we think needs to go so we can really focus on the highly profitable parts of our business that we think have long-term growth potential. So we're not -- so we'll see what happens. I would expect that certainly, things start to at least stabilize there, if not, start to slow down. But until we go through the actual details of what our businesses have in mind for next year, it's hard to comment.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then within your 35-or-so-percent incremental margin targets, how should we think about how much of that is driven by pricing versus volume? headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pricing is not a big margin driver for us here. Really, the big margin driver is and has been, I think Scott mentioned 12 quarters in a row of the Enterprise Initiatives. That's really what's driving the margin expansion. And the incremental margins, if y
componenttext: Pricing is not a big margin driver for us here. Really, the big margin driver is and has been, I think Scott mentioned 12 quarters in a row of the Enterprise Initiatives. That's really what's driving the margin expansion. And the incremental margins, if you go back and look historically, that's where the company's been for a very long time, in that 30% to 35% range. And really, on the pricing side, all we're trying to do is to offset some material cost inflation, but it's not the key driver of our growth or of our margin expansion.

componenttextpreview: No, there's really nothing interesting to report. I mean, like I think I said, all we're trying to do is offset to the extent that there is material cost inflation, that's -- we're trying to offset that with price. We've been in this 10 to 20 basis points
componenttext: No, there's really nothing interesting to report. I mean, like I think I said, all we're trying to do is offset to the extent that there is material cost inflation, that's -- we're trying to offset that with price. We've been in this 10 to 20 basis points range for a number of quarters here, actually, longer than that, and we expect to stay in that range on a go-forward basis.

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay, I guess there's a perception that some of these material costs are starting to go up. Are you seeing that and you're just able to price for it? Or is that not consistent with what you're saying?

headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not seeing any material cost inflation at this point. And when we do, we will react, like I said, and do our best in the divisions to offset that with efficiency and with price.
componenttext: We're not seeing any material cost inflation at this point. And when we do, we will react, like I said, and do our best in the divisions to offset that with efficiency and with price.

And then second, I guess when I look at your Construction revenues on an organic basis, it's still up, but obviously, the increases are declining. headline: Illinois Tool Works Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: So I think on the free cash flow, like I said, on a year-to-date basis, we're exactly where we were last year. So there's -- things can move around a little bit on a quarterly basis. For example, our CapEx number is up a little bit this quarter, but year-to-date, it's exactly in line with last year. And then maybe some larger payments that go out 1 quarter versus another. We fully expect we'll be at above 100% for the year, which would imply a strong Q4, which, seasonally, that's what we usually do. So other than that, feel very good about the free cash flow performance. And on the Construction side, I'd just add, similar to what we said earlier, I mean, demand is pretty steady state. There's some comp issues that we're dealing with, but we feel good about the -- using current run rates to model the fourth quarter and we're not expecting any big changes from where we are right now.
